Entry.1:
24.1918

For travels on this day the last diary will give full details. Sufficient it is to say that I returned to night in a car with Major Blake from Salisbury to Codford St Mary
Entry.2:
Christmas day & the most miserable I have ever passed. I started the day with disappointment & melancholy followed in its steps! 

To day the Countess of Harrowby was giving a dance & party & I did so much wish to see how an Englishman of the better class spent his Xmas Day & to see with what traditions he had surrounded it this one day. Though last night the Major was agreable to day the adjutant refused to hear of leave as orders had been issued forbidding Officers to travel on the trains on that day. 

So the day commenced filled with regrets for what might have been & the wish of seeing an Englishman of the better type celebrate this festival on his own hearth was lost. 

At dinner all officers were present to see the

2

men & on return to quarters I found several actresses more or less on the way to intoxication who greeted all & sundry with maudlin mirth. Such was very different to my tastes this day & only excited a feeling of disgust. 

At dinner I was the only silent officer who refused to take part in the hilarity. Everyone had bon bons which gave either trumpets or caps & paper hats. Champagne was supplied & catering arrangement under Richards 31st Bn excellent. Richards address is Tattersalls Club Adelaide.

After dinner I retire to my room & with memories of whose case is still proceeding in the papers long for the drugs that bring forgetfulness. Strange it is years since this thought crossed my mind & that it should recur on the happiest day of the Church year. Then I went for a long walk among undulating hills & half closed in valleys which destitute of bush or life well accorded with my gloomy thoughts & when on the way back I was lost the unison was complete. 

One incident will always stand out & that was the “drowsy tinkling of a distant field". The sheep there are enclosed in little portable

fences & the accumulation of sheep meant a massing of the little different note bells which are suspended from their neck & tinkle as they browse.

After dinner Pearce Hook came into my room & we adjourned to bar & made merry for the night. Moore came along afterwards & forgot he was in anothers mess. To night we each got a parcel from the Comfort Fund ctg cheese, lemon butter, cocoa cigarettes & butter scotch. Thus passed Christmas Day 1918
Entry.3:
This morning enjoyed luxury of staying in bed till nearly noon 

As I am piquet officer for the night I am unable to accompany some of the chaps to Salisbury fortunately for me as they got into a grand row with a taxi driver. 

On piquet there is no where I can stay & I yarn with a police man who finally introduces me to a Belgian refugee Malleanna soon to leave for Rue de Voltaire Paris & I have have an interesting yarn with her in French promising to return to morrow night if

4

time permits as I am going to London to bring a leave party back. There is nothing to do. You catch the same train as party & get out at your destination & go home. It means a pleasant little trip at Government expense though it involves a lot of travelling
Entry.4:
Rose 5 am as uncertain what hour train will move but a party moves off at 6 am. Train arrives 10 am Waterloo. Report to RTO & meet Clarke who gives me photos of lodge. 

I then visit Countess of Harrowby to thank her for my trip to Northumberland. Here I meet Digby who has been out in Mespot & is now in a London Hospital drawing 2 pays until a ship sails for Australia 

We dine at Au Peut Riche & I give a book to Elise Drumont 15 Stacey St London Then with Digby visit Kennedy & say good bye – then to Alcocks but office is closed – to Ballie Tea Rooms St Marys Axe then I leave Digby as I have promised Lady Gore to take tea with her. 

Here I met Miss Muriel Seymour of 34

Montpelier Square London S.W. a very fascinating though not pretty girl whom I interested very much by much conversation & who much regrets my departure for a dance which Lady Baker Wilbraham of 34 Lancaster Gate has invited me has invited dancing commence at 6 & my train goes at 7 so I have just one dance make my apologies & catch train to Codford on the mud as it is commonly called. 

Meet the Belge who is quite joyful as she has received her passports & leaves for Paris on Monday. Reach home about midnight having travelled since 5 am this morning & then commence to pack as my goods must be ready by 8-30 am tomorrow for France

28 December 1918

It is not yet certain whether I am to go or to remain for the trial of the orderly who stole so much of my kit & service revolver – & from which I recovered nothing. My goods were sent on & at last minute when others were about to start I received orders to sail but had to get my service issue first ie steel

6

Helmet, codene, leather jacket & gas mask or box respirator. I have not time to collect respirator & sail without it. Train leaves 10.30 am & we take taxi leaving Codford St Marys & St Peter in grand style

The journey to Southampton is uneventful & countryside I have described before except that now owing to the rains the low lying land is a bog & the streams are slightly larger. The whole land still retains that verdant green.

We arrive at Southhampton at about 1 pm. – report to Officer & then acting on his advice dine although our movement order stated that it was impossible to get any food on the way. We dined at Princes Restaurant & then marched up & town the town. There is little to see save the old gate through which the trams pass & which congests the crowds through the other two arches. 

We enter Savoy Café a lively place hung with flags. The number of people in the streets is enormous & they seem to have little to do as one meets the same faces over & over again. The results of the elections are due to night & perhaps this accounts for the crowd.

I & an Eng officer dine at the

Dolphin Hotel & we report back & go on board our ship “" a Yankee boat about 50 ft out of water & drawing 15 ft. built for coastal trade & unable to face heavy weather 

The whole superstructure has been strutted to save her falling to pieces on the way across & some passages are impassable owing to struts & in all the top cabins a beam prevents the door being closed. All water & basins have been taken out of cabins owing to their ill use by officers. One & only latrine we can find open has 3 ins of water on floor & is still rising. Soon some one may be interested enough to stop it but at present none of the Yankees seem to care. Blankets are on issue but no one can find that particular officer & the crew are not obliging & will not look for any one for you. The Yank with an eye to business retails coffee & a slice of bread for 1/- to us. 

We move off about 7 pm but wait down off the Admiralty as we must enter Havre on the high water. I meet two french hospital men & we yarn till late into the night till I turn in. The sea comes up rough & the tub does some pretty
Entry.5: antics but the only thing which worries me is the banging of the door, none of which one can keep fastened owing to the rolling. However I jam it with paper & sleep on.
Entry.6:
This morning at 7 am we entered in France – the land that for over 4 years has been the scence of turmoil & carnage, of stress & patriotism. All seems peaceful here & save for the uniforms & while the activity is such as one would meet in any large seaport town. 

We go ashore like a gang of school girls frightened to lose each other. My importance has increased as I alone can speak French. I have Badeker with me & the names of the streets & restaurants & know where I am going. 

We pass a YMCA hostel & all decide to enter. This was originally the Hotel D’Angleterre but has been taken over by the YMCA as an officers rest house. It is thronged with Americans who seem to be in every little hamlet of this country. After this meal we report & are told to be in camp by 11 am As this is impossible I do not attempt to reach there but spend some hours in Havre with Davies

The whole life of the town

centres in one street the Rue de Paris Tortonis the popular café is a great hotel like building with a little square in front of it. The park in front of the imposing Hotel de Ville is simple but forms a pleasant oasis among the buildings & a happy ending to the many streets that converge here.

I visited the old church & thence on to Quay. Plans of the city are in Badeker so I will not repeat. Took tram for Harfleur & then had ½ hour walk to reach No 12 camp only to find this was not our real home but that the AIBD is some miles further on & through mud we flounder til we reach our destination. 

We have an officer returning to duty with us & the camp has contracted since his departure. There are now only two camps one for convalescent & the other is the base. Here we are well received & alloted to little canvas cubicules strange that after 4 yrs the Base should not have some more permanent form of abode. 

After a short address at 2 pm we were free to go on leave & not knowing how long I shall be here I take full advantage of the leave & with Davies proceed to Havre 

The exit from camp is different to that by which we approached & is between two rows of very high poplar trees which fringe each side of the road which

The girl conductress on the tram have a running fire of wit & badinage which keeps everyone in good humour & offends no one. On return to camp slept on the floor.
Entry.7:
This morning we have to go through a gas test with our respirators & walk nearly 1 ½ miles to reach the place. The road winds through a picturesque wood up a hill through some old monastery & along to a tear gas shed & then along to chlorine cave & whence we can obtain a splendid view of St Addresse where once stood a Casino now a hospital.

In the afternoon so that I do not waste any time I go down to one of the quaintest little towns I have seen. In the centre is a large square & on its edge a church now time & weatherworn but still maintaining its grandeur & sanctity which ages have not been able to mar. In the centre of the square is an old village fountain from which every woman draws her water & from an adjoining trough horses are watered. 

Visit M. Hoche Rue Cadot but no one at home & return to camp but return to in the

12

evening & then walk back. The French villa is a square edifice ugly but well placed back from the road & seems like a box in a paddock ie in this part. On arrival in camp receive orders to leave for battalion to morrow.
Entry.8: Unable to leave camp as we are under orders. During morning draft is cancelled & then is changed to a stand by & finally we report 7 pm to Camp Adjutant No 12 camp – get into motor lorries & whizz off to station Gare des Maritimes & find the train a collection of goods wagons with one
Entry.9:
class carriage & 1 first class with the windows broken. 

I find myself in a
Entry.11:
class here either are a long carriage with wooden seats & backs or else these backs are continued for 5 ft & thus make some little privacy. However sleep save from exhaustion is impossible The soldiers are happier because they can stretch their limbs at full length & have a brazier whilst officers must perish as compartment is too small for a brazier

Happily we finish the journey in 2 days & 2 nights. Formerly the same journey took about 10 days. We started at 7 pm & in the morning found ourselves at Amiens having passed Rouen during 

the night. Rumour had it that we disembarked at Rouen & stayed there a few day but onward ever onward is the motto of our train & after a stay of about 2 hours we move forward.
Entry.12:
Having spent all night in the train we all feel happy that a new year has dawned but wish we were still in our billets in Le Havre. We had all remained awake to see the New Year in 

This day is very interesting for we pass through the battle area & Somme passing Pozieres, Roisel, St Quentin, Peronne, Most of these places are a collection of ruined houses though in some the inhabitants are returning though the buildings are clearly unsafe. Most of these towns will be easier rebuilt by putting the new town in another place as the towns are now only rubbish heaps which must be cleared away first. 

As we approach the battle area we find dug outs in railway cuttings & then isolated shell craters & then ring upon ring of barbed wire entanglements. In fact a barb wire entanglement then open level spaces & trenches interpolated constitute the general aspect of this battle area. Occassionally one sees a mound of earth with a cross on which
Entry.13:
is placed a steel helmet which alone tells of some forgotten act of heroism or sacrifice. 

Cemeteries we pass none. All seems peaceful & deserted on these fields which but lately teemed with armies & 
heard the
 resounded shriek of shell & cries of dying men. So pass away man & his little works to get place in the silent majesty of the Great Architect & his works. Thus they pass these men children of the sword & in their place the grass grows green the greener where the blood has run thickest – the ruined village alone remaining as silent testimony to mans destructive power – & in a few years even these will have passed away. 

Already in Belgium one can see the peasants cutting up the wire entanglements & putting them in little heaps so that the land may once more come under the share. 

That night we arrive at Souslesne or some name like it (Solesmes) We arrive here at 7.30 pm & do not move till 10.30 when we go on till 1.30 & stand still for the rest of the night. Finding during the day that there was a compartment in which there were only 2 officers one of whom was Hatton I transfer here for the night but find that the backs of the seats are not raised as in my own carriage & that a few broken

windows do not add to the warmth of the carriage. However I get some little sleep.
Entry.15:
Ribecourt; Marcoing, Noyelles, Cambrai, St Vaast, Solesmes, Le Quesnoy, Valenciennes, Jemappe, Mons, Thielt, Strepy, La Louviere, Managy, Luttre, Gosselies, Jumet, Le Roux, Charleroi) 

At daylight find the train at a standstill & on making a tour find that we have arrived at Mons. I shave with water drawn from the engine & with another officer wander into the town for something to eat or drink. 

I ask a man where we can obtain some eggs & he tells me that the Germans have taken all their fowls & live stock & that eggs are unprocurable while bread is at exorbitant rates. I asked him if one could get a cup of coffee at a café whose sign I saw down the street. He said yes but insisted on coming into his house & introduced us to his wife. While she was getting the café he gave us 2 glasses of cognac which put some warmth into us. 

The Belgian with recent memories of German oppression cannot do enough for their liberators. This was not an isolated case of hospitality but only one of many recurring cases. 

We return to train which has already started but only goes as far as station a few hundred yards & rests for another 1 hour during which I pay a visit to

16

the railway station. Like all stations here the platform is only about 1 ft above the rails & the passengers must needs climb up into the carriage. The number of rails here is enormous, but all the passenger lines pass through an enormous shed with glass ends which constitutes the station. 

About 9 am the train moves on having been travelling 200 yds. 

Our destination is still unknown – no one has been told where we are going though now it seems certain that Charleroi is our destination as some members of train are going there. 

Ultimately the train arrives there about 4 pm & we report to Corp HQ. Here the procedure is most casual no ones seems to care whether we sleep here for ever or go for a holiday. We go for a walk down the town to reach which we must cross the Canal. The pic give a good description of the town. I am forwarding about 36. 

One passes up the main street into a grand square in which is situated Café Central the popular resort of officers – from a corner of this square a street leads across the river & up the hill to the upper part of the town in which is another square though it is not surrounded by such life or buildings as in the lower part of the town yet it contains the principal church which I took to be the

Town Hall & the gendarmerie. I go there & get a billet for night in Hotel de l’Esperance which costs me nothing. I do not relish sleeping in a rough military blanket on the floor when a comfortable bed between sheets is to be had for the asking. 

However not liking the look of the hotel & hearing that if I went to any large house & asked for accomodation I could receive it so I walked down the Boulevard near the river & when I had selected the biggest house I went in & asked for owner noting on my way that the word “notaire" appeared on the plate. Monsieur was not in but Madame told me I could speak before her as before her husband. I explained what I had heard & she immediately showed me a room or rather the maid did. I told her I would be back about 9 & left. 

In the town I met an English officer & together we went to Café Central which consists of one large room with a balcony running round the top. On ground floor dancing takes place & partners are anyone you like. The orchestra renders good music & in intervals there is two or more paid singers who sing & then make a collection on their own behalf. The scene is lively but the mirth is forced a little it seems to me & has not the spontaneousness one finds in a Parisian café perhaps this is due to the English element or to the proximity

18

of Germany & Lenton blood. 

Leaving this we wander in the street which is full of people. I speak to every pretty girl I can find on some pretext or another & if I stayed there several days I should be extremely comfortable. Among others I met a widow whose friendship I gain unwittingly by my defence of her in English which it turns out she can understand perfectly.

Among others I met one Yvonne from 407 Rue de Beaumont Marcionelles with whom I take a walk through the town. There visit the EFC Club just opened & not quite settled down at present. Though it is the cheapest & best place for a meal 4 fr. Then tired out I slip along to his hotel & then after looking at two girls who move up & down the street escorted by a man who walks a few places in front & are probably female detectives I adjourn to my notaires place to find him waiting. 

He greets me in 
cordial
 courtly fashion & ask how I came to select his house. I tell him that I am of the devils brigade like himself We adjourn to fireside & I am introduced to the bosom of the family.

3 January 1919

This morning I have decided to run up to Bruxelles if I can obtain Coghills permission. Eade & Betts both tell me I am a fool to risk being AWL but subsequently use my idea themselves leaving me in

the lurch by not saying I am going & allowing me by their silence to be detailed to remain with a party 

However at this moment I am quite unconscious of the fact & go forth & visit for 1 fr the Music Anatomique a collection of wax figures & pictures illustrating VD in all its hideousness. I used my French to explain to a party of diggers the import of the explanation especially in a fictitious development of the embryo

Then went on to Musée Archaelogique but it closed at 11.30 am & as it was now 11.20 am it had taken time by the forelock & entry was impossible. I then met two girls & asked my way to the university. They were going to Mons in a car & offered me a trip. The ability to speak French does wonders for a man here. 

I visit the university to which is attached a Technical school but do not go through the building minutely as it has recently been a German hospital & there are numerous officers still in occupation there. I then return to café Cristal & Café La Rose near canal. 

On going back to Corp HQ I find myself detailed to remain & try to get out of it but find it impossible unless I can find another officer. This is impossible as they had all left. However I waste the whole afternoon at Café Central Club & in the streets looking for another officer but in

20

vain.

While at Corps I am told that my pay book has been discovered though I was unaware of its loss. I go to Railway & obtain it & then go to Paymaster to get some cash but find that it is mutilated & the most important pages torn out & that I can obtain no money. This is unfortunate as I had decided to let the duty slide & visit Bruxelles & any other large town that came my way. However the PM promises me an advance if I can get an identification from Corp. 

I go to night to Café Central & met Man whom I last saw at Liverpool in the 4th Bn. He introduces me to two of his friends both Gaby one of whom is french & the other Belgian. When Café is closed I go to supper in a little café & met one of the Gabys I dine with a of 2nd Div. & then wander about street & put up in a private hotel

4–1–1919

As I had seen adjutant & been officially relieved of my command I take my time to day for my trip to Bruxelles with or without pay is decided on. I shave & wash in my rooms at the annexe of L’Hotel de l’Europe & visit Paymaster who generously advances me 200 f (£7.13.4) just on my word that I have cash

in my book. This is quite unusual for Pay Corp but I suppose my face marks me as honest. 

I breakfast at Camp where it costs 1 fr. per meal & in town 5/10 fr. & set out to visit Musée Archaelogique in company with an Eng army doctor whom I picked up on my ramble. The Musée is disappointing inasmuch the articles are not described though the relics from a neighbouring Roman villa are very interesting. 

At 2 pm I go to catch train. It is full but at a platform near by there is another train going at 2.35 pm direct without changing so I get on this train Both trains are without their engines 2.30 pm 3 pm 3.30 pm no engines. Ask guard which train the 2 or 2.30 will start first & he replies whichever engine arrives first perhaps the 2.35 pm train

Meanwhile in the yard several engines are shunting & coupling up until a train composed of 8 engines is formed & they sail up and down yard. At least about 4.45 our engine arrives & we set out after the 2 pm train. We pass nr Ludr where the Germans masses their rolling stock & set fire to it during their retreat lest the stock should fall into our hands. Houses ¼ mile away have been shattered by the force of the explosions which the track has been torn up as if mined or

22

bombed. 

The 2 pm train which has a staff of 5 officials on engines gets as far as Bonlieu & all its passengers transfer to our train. In the carriage I occupy there were 3 Railwaymen & they are like monkeys. They find some netting in the carriage & they tear it all down. Still they are courteous to me & finding a warmer carriage invite me to accompany them & to share their food They were very rough but hospital to a stranger nevertheless.

After Bonlieu the carriage is full beyond even standing capacity but this worries no one & eventually I reach Bruxelles at 6 pm. Re my luggage – there is some dispute but as I am a soldier it passes off I then look for RTO but cannot find one only a Belgian Colonel who directs me to Café deil’Ete’ near for all information.

On arrival I find that this is released prisoners depot in charge of a Scottish officer. He outlines a plan of tour for me & the best way of spending evening. Apparently I can still get in at the Opera & I go without dinner or lodging. Opera is too good to miss. On way I get my hair brushed which costs me f50 & buy a little piece of bath brick alleged to be soap for 3 fr. 

On arrival at Opera where one play La Tosca there is standing room only for 9 fr but two English officers inform me that

it is worth the price to see the theatre & indeed it is. The tiers rise one over the over one mass of burnished gold. Five in number & shallow only accomodating 2 rooms. The whole is aglow with gold & illumed by a grand chandelier in the centre while the whole roofed is frescoed & panels painted wherever possible Cast was

Mario Cavaradossi – MM Fanseau

Le Baron Scarpia – H Albers

Le Sacrusian – L Van Obbeigh

Cesare Angelotti – Lehantraine

Spoletta – Radoux

Sciarrone – Coutelia

Floria Tosca – Mde Edvina

Un Patre – Prick

Mde Edvina a very pretty woman, d’une elegance exquise, est une artiste de grand autorite, et son talent, qui est remarquables son art au chant qui est la perfection meme, sa voix dramatique a une belles qualite, tres etendues, firent tres grande impression. Albers acting was really good The conductor was M. Cornell de Lhoran. 

When Theatre was out about 11 pm I met an Australian officer who insisted we should dine & so at 11 pm we commenced our meal. This is not late as city is only just coming to life & all the night is still before it. We did not eat much 3 courses & yet it cost 43 fr. Food is very dear here & the Princes Restaurant

24

not an extravagant place. 

After dinner I go to Merry Grill a cafe full of life & jollity. Here dancing, singing, love making, drinking & gaiety unrestrained gladden the heart of this weary soldier Everyone is so natural that gaiety infects even my sluggish English blood There is no forced laughter or idiotic & clumsy attempts to appear gay. They are naturally gay & enjoying themselves because they are expressing their feelings & not because pleasure is a duty.

I am quite at home in this atmosphere & enjoy myself immensely. One pretty little Dutch girl Lessy Bongen Rue de Brabant 216 contributing much to my pleasure because I am Australian. 

During the night I wander round in Madrid Cafe in Rue Pont Neuf & Queen Victoria in 40 Galerie de Commerce (Rue Heuve) La Gaiete & Bruxelles Remesse but return to Merry Grill which I leave at 2.45 am though the crowd is still there. Among the crowd are two French aviators & excellent fellows they are. The night has been one of the pleasantest I have passed & though I had no money I 
saw
 had a lot of fun.
Entry.16:
I sleep till 9 am this morning & then set off to Railway to collect my razor & hair brushes. However the station is

closed & military guard put on so I wander around unshaven till about 3 pm. 

Trams here are free & the whole city is encircled by boulevards. By taking certain trams & changing at certain places the complete circuit can be made The Belgian who tells me this goes out of his way to put me on the tram. They are so grateful to be free of the German occupation that nothing is too much trouble for them. The tram pass all the sights Palace, musée, etc (see pic). 

I return & get out & visit Palais de Justice the largest building in Europe & who immense proportions stagger the imagination & leave one spell bound & awestrucken. Entrance is forbidden as this is Sunday but I open a door & sail in, find someone & explain my wish & the shortness of my stay & a guide & a Belgian law student show me over. The Place des Pas Perdus under the dome & the vast staircase still more bewilder one with their vastness. The only word I could use to express to my friends was that it was “immense" 

I then take tram to Bois de Cambre a pretty wooded parc with a large lake & wooded isle in the midst on which island is build a rustic village hidden by trees & shrubs. A restaurant with iced drinks exists in the centre though never closed

26

a beautiful poplar walk 6 yds wide with tall graceful trees about every 3 yds is truly wonderful while the valleys that cross the wood have been accentuated & the numerous which bubble along add rustic picturesqueness to a woodland scene of unrivalled beauty. Every where bridges have been constructed the handrails are made of concrete in imitation of tree limbs & thus do no jar on ones asthetic perceptions. 

From the Bois I return to Colonne du Congres a monument guarded by two ?4 lions & surmounted by a stature of Leopold 1 raised to commemorate the formation of the kingdom. It has a balcony round the top which is reached by climbing 185 steps through inky blackness but is worth the trouble as the view from the top is worth the effort. Leaving here I find my way to the Grand Place perhaps the finest in Europe ie surrounded by the finest & most historical buildings (see pic)

The Hotel de Ville takes ones breath away & before one can appreciate its graceful beauty the Maison du Roi completes the mystification of the intellect. Thence I visit the Church of St Cadulle where a funeral is in progress. The interior of church is as magnificent as the exterior & that is sufficient to say. 

Then I visit a lace manufacturing place but disappoint the proprietor as I do not buy any having no cash. Thence I go to Place Royale

so called because there is a stature of the first King of Jerusalem who happened to be one of the Dukes of Brabant. 

Thence I catch the tram for Le park & 
colonnade
 arcade de 
Quis
 Cinquantenaire – a colossal edifice erected to commemorate the 50 years of Belgian inaugeration as a nation. It is used as an exhibition building but now as a park for ASC. The view over park & up the Boulevard is a glorious setting to this magnificent monument of inspired commemoration. 

.

The lofty arcade & arch are on the same immense proportions which seem to characterise this part of the world.

I the take the tram to Tervueren & it is the most glorious trip I have ever taken. Away for nearly an hour we pass by parks with rippling streams & cascades & then dive through a grand forest miles in extent whose severed aspect & stems without a branch are of a natural beauty unknown in our part of the world.

At Tervueren there is a colonial museum much patronised by visiting colonial officers & well worth the trouble of an inspection. I then return to city & running short of funds dine at a cheap cafe but it cost 9 fr for a fish & a glass of beer. Food is very scarce here & prices are out of all proportion to the ordinary. I have had a

28

big day & am sleepy so go along to Hotel St Jean & find a big room with two double beds & turn in.

6 January 1919

Train has left as 6-20 this morning & as I arrive at 8 am I do not catch it. There is some trouble with the ticket & it costs me 12 fr. to go as far as Tille for I will not pay fare right through. As Antwerp is near a trip fills in the morning but there is nothing to say about it except that it is a big commercial city intersected by canals & block with punts & shipping. 

On return visit museum of old arms & cannons at Port de Hal one of the old gates of the ancient city of Bruxelles. From here you catch a blue tram to the field of (V) Waterloo which does not repay the time (1 hr) spent in reaching it. The pc gives all that is to be seen. 

On return I take tram to Grimberghen as far as the other side of the city as Tervueren is on south? passing on the way the Royal Park with a grand tower monument & old time plain looking building once a palace, then past Japanese Tower erected as a monument & also a chinese palace.

Returning to city I must look around for dinner & find a friend in need who takes me to several places & finally I dine very well in a little restaurant

unknown to the ordinary world. Here between the hours of 12 & 2 one can dine on 4 frs & get 1 potage & 2 plats meats vegetable & potatoes, cheese. Here beefsteak costs 5 fr & cold meat 2 slices 2 f50 After the meal I walk into a shop & purchase a scent bottle & some pc & yarn till nearly 11 pm

Then I seek an hotel de bon Esperance but there is no hope for me as it is full – However porter knows of another place near by & as close to station as this. I leave by 6.20 am train & do not wish to go up town Here at 64 I find a room 5 fr. & proprietor tells me that 50 centimes is enough for girl who calls me in the morning. Bed is very comfy & room is large as good as any London hotel

7-1-1919

(Amiens, Villers Bretonneux, Bayonvillers, Wiencourt, Rosieres, Lihons, Chaulnes, Fresnes, , Le Mesnil, Peronne, , Courvilles Roisel, Crepy, Gonnelieu, Ribecourt)

This morning I am called at 5 am & have coffee before leaving ask for a little bread & make a good breakfast for I do not know where I shall get the next. The girl enquires if she shall give me any for the train & I say yes. I do not eat this until 3 days after & then it is all that I have for the day & in my heart I blessed that girl a dozen times over. 

Aboard the train with my luggage which costs me 1 fr every time anyone touches it. I find a first class carriage & settle down in it. We move off punctually & passed several places more or less destroyed by the Huns or by our airmen. one seems to 

 

pass Hal Enghien, Leuze Lowndi Lille

30

have had a particularly bad time. All the bridges across the line have been blown up by the Huns & are being rebuilt temporarily by British Railway Units.

On train meet a Masonic friend alongside of me & am set as expression goes. I arrive at Lille but according to my friend the only railway station in Lille is out of use & this station Gare de Porte D’Arras is where we get out. I have some doubts but as there is an RTO get out. Time is now 2 pm & this train the Bruxelles Paris Express has for the bigger part of journey travelled at about 5 KM per hour. RTO I must travel on to Abbeville by reinforcement day which left ½ hr ap. This gives me a day in Lille so I am satisfied. 

Lill is a large straggling commercial town but half an hours walk will show you the best part of it Walking from station you meet the Port D’Arras an ancient gateway still intact. Then street leads up to a church round both sides of which the street continues its courses forming a little island of the church Road leads into Place de la Revolution with the Praefecture at one end & the Palais des Beaux Arts on other side which has been stripped of all its contents by the retreating Huns.

These two imposing building set off the square. Passing thence past a statue to Faidherbe I enter the Grand Place not nearly so large as last square but more the heart

of the city. Here are situated all the Cafes & just off it the Hotel Moderne (where a room for night costs 25f) Bouise, Theatre Taverne Royale (now an EFC Officers Club) are all situated. The main thorofares are all thronged & in the square one finds little crowds assembled & finds singers selling the songs & at intervals singing them & teaching them to the crowd. 

Fall in with an English officer & with 3 girls with whom we go as far as a cafe & then leave them The proprietor of an adjoining cafe wants 25 fr for bottle of Red Medoc wine.

I return to Club & dine not having had any luncheon for the day Here I met 2 Canadians & have sundry whiskies After dinner meet a Scotch officer & set off for a Cafe Moderne where one can laugh & play & dance. However this place is closed we wander off to (*) Rue de la Bassee where I part company from my friends. I continue to wander round town but cannot get a room though there are plenty in the town because the cafes & hotels have been closed to soldier at 9 pm by APM. 

At Hotel de la Place I met two other Canadian Officer Major McDonald & hearing of my plight they say they will not see me stranded & hunt round with me & then put me in their car after a visit to Cafe

(*)L’entente Cordiale 7 Rue de la Vieille Comedie near Grand Place 5 o’clock Officers, Pianola, 

32

Moderne upstairs & I am whizzed off to their camp at Le Sart, but which they call Brencq. Here the major produces a bottle & cigars & gives me the palliasse off his bed & unlimited number of overcoats I doss quite comfortably for the night

8 January 1919

This morning I only wake at 9 am & decide to miss the train at 10.30 & so have breakfast in bed & then have a warm bath with which this private house is fitted, shave & set out for Lille. I had hardly gone very far when the Major overtook me in his car & I got a lift into Lille.

On way in we pass an anchored balloon round which 5 aeroplanes are circling & passed some Algerian troops leading spare horses. Also some french cavalry with spare horses. Their seats are not good & they ride badly. 

I then take tram for Roubaix. Each section costs 5 centimes. The tram ticket is marked on top with the hours & on bottom with days of week (letters only). We pass du Romarin, St Mur, Le Buisson (it is not visible) Croise Laroche, Wasquehal, Le Sart, Velodrome, Pere Barbieux, Roubaix where I get out. Nearby is Tourcoing, Leers & Hem but so far the tram has not commenced to run to these localities

for the city has not long been liberated & every overhead bridge is in ruins across the track. 

Roubaix is more a residential resort from Lille It has narrow streets & 2 squares in one of which is found the Town Hall & the old Church marked like most churches here with the words Liberté Fraternité Egalité, so marked same way as said because these things no longer exist in France & the church is a fitting sepulchure for 
them
 past ideas.

I return to Lille after passing through Park at Roubaix. In Lille I try to cash a cheque but as it is Australian Bank they refuse. British Paymaster cannot give me money because I am Australian & so I must carry on with what I have. In afternoon I spend at Club with diary notes & dine there in evening for 4fr. Bed costs 2 fr. I go for walk round city after dinner & then turn in.
Entry.17:
On rising this morning find I have lost my cigarette case & thinking it might be at Brencq I set out for it having just enough time to reach there & catch train. Unfortunately the case is not there & it takes me all my time to reach Railway by 10.30. 

However I need not have hurried as train does not arrive till 12 & is then shunted into a

34

siding to allow a passenger express with dining saloon & wine on tables filled with civilians to pass through. Peace is not yet signed & yet civilians are taking not equal rights with soldiers but the preference. 

At 3.45 our train moves out & at 8 pm has done 18 KM & anchors for the next 6 hours outside the La Bassee Canal. Night is clear & cold but as I have blankets in my valise I am quite comfy. All this day I have had nothing to eat when I bethink me of the bread & butter I got in Brussels & a pot of cheddar cheese in my valise & this constitutes all the meals I have this day.

I have an ASC officer with me but otherwise the carriage a 1st class is to ourselves & we can stretch out
Entry.18:
Train is alternately crawling & halting & at Calonne Ricquart. When all my friends leave me to catch fast train for which we have been side tracked. Having my valise I remain as it is too much trouble to move it. This day there is nothing to eat & though train often halts 3 to 4 hours yet she may go at any minute & it is not safe to move away from train. 

We pass through Bethune & thence on to St Pol. Here I find some Aust. soldiers in train & ask them how food supply is – tell them I am hungry & am taken given a tin of bully beef & 3 or 4 slices of toast bread & jam – also a cup of tea which

I manage to get down for lunch. 

We pass two depots for tanks at one of which there must have been at least 200 in rows. On return to my carriage I find Col Dicken of Shropshire & Junior Carlton Club in my compartment & we have a good yarn. 

After much slow progress we reach Etaples. The usual time of journey for a troop train is 7 ½ hrs & yet we are 29 hours late. Have supper at the Etaples Club for 2 fr. I have 2 large plates of meat & chips & go down to station to catch train at midnight. However as she does not go till 2 am I sleep in a YMCA on the station at railway yard & am called at 2. Train however is no hurry & does not leave till 4.20. We have a brasier in waggon there are no carriages on train & towards morning feel the effects so badly that I have to hang outside the train to get fresh air.
Entry.19:
Arrived at Abbeville. There is another officer getting out here G H Jones 227 Field Coy RE-BEF. He say that if I throw out my valise at the cloak room it will save being carried back. He throws it out & it immediately falls back under the train & is hopelessly cut about & covered in grease. So dirty is it that the disagreeable chap in cloakroom refused to take it

36

& I am thus compelled to leave it on the station but I ask the police to look after it for me. What the extent of the damage is I cannot say at present. Then to EFC for breakfast & find Molesworth who left Havre 10 days after me has arrived at the same time. 

Then I have to report to Bienfay where Div. Wing HQ is situated & must find my own way there. No one ASC or traffic police seem to have heard of the place. Tommy soldiers are the most stupid & unobserving creatures on earth & though they passed a place once a day or worked in this locality for nearly 3 years they cannot tell you anything. 

However I have a map which I borrowed from an ASC office & get my bearing. Hop on first empty lorries & by dint of asking for Blaigny which is some distance on the same road get somewhere further on track. Then lorry turns aside so walk a part of way but finally hop on a limber full of cauliflowers which takes me with 5 KM of places which I traverse per boot. 

Here I am told to report somewhere else Feuquieres. Have dinner at wing & then return in a lorry to Abbeville as there is a train leaving at 7.20 pm which will take me right into the village of 

Feuquieres. I wander about Abbeville & then go to Club for dinner (4f) as the end of the trip is in sight & I need not husband my cash at the expense of my stomach. Dine with Redfern Jock Stewart & leave in middle of meal to catch train. 

On arrival at station I find my luggage has disappeared & miss train in order to look for it I then proceed to tell off the military police & the french railway official in a way that must have been laughable to any onlooker. However this will not find the valise & I decide to wait till morning to consider what is best to be done.

There is no room at the Club for a bed & I try Tete de Boef then Hotel de la France & several other places but unsuccessfully & go to Club & sleep in a chair in a warm room. For the last 3 nights I have been sleeping in the train & am so tired that I go to sleep straight away & do not wake up till 6 am the following morning.
Entry.20:
Awoke much refreshed after my sleep & breakfast (3f 50). I then travel out to wing to see if my kit has been taken there by mistake but all to no effect – it is not

38

there. 

Then return to Railway & meet one of the police who tells me that my orderly came to him on station & asked where baggage was stored – looked around & picked up my port put it into a cab & took it away to the officers club where I am staying for 3 days. This is the story & I can see straight away that it is all a put up job & that valise is stolen Police can identify cab which took valise away & I spent all afternoon looking for the man. 

Towards evening I gave 50c to each of two cabbies & ask them to find out. They succeed & this chap tells me he took the valise to a certain spot near which there are only 4 houses. I try to get gendarmes to enter & search but they need a warrant or “perquisition" so reluctantly I take the train for camp meeting

Lt Shannon who takes me to Battalion HQ – where I am told to billet with A. be alloted to B & detailed to Education officer. I report to B Coy Capt Dixon & find Scotson & Molesworth there. He is a self opiniated crawler but his treatment of me is excellent: Scotson is mess & learning that I have had nothing since breakfast provides what the larder can furnish which

I appreciate in my lonliness I sleep in Beatons room to night with plenty of blankets & a smell of unwashed linen.
Entry.21:
Capt Dixon arranges leave for me to go into Abbeville to search for my kit as I intend to search these 4 houses where the previous night the old man who joined in argument with cabbies had made judicious enquiries. I get hold of Roper but he says I do not need him & then go to APM & with 2 men visit the house with green shutters then a house of a Belgian refugee & then the café at . 

This man does not realise that I am an Aussie because I am wearing a cap but he is full up to the neck with Australian who smash in his place. The police tell me they believe there is a gang of robbers working in Abbeville some of whom pose as officers & some as diggers. Disappointed I return to Club & write up diary & then catch train to camp. There are two nice ladies in same compartment one of whom reminds me of Lucia. 

At camp I report to A Coy mess for I have been transferred to this company but

40

finding no officers in the mess I return to B Coy have supper & then take Beatons billet again.
Entry.22:
This morning I breakfast with A Coy & then visit billets at 9 am am allotted to No 2 platoon. Routine here consists of breakfast 8.15 am. visit billets 9 to 9.30 then loiter around football field till10.45. fall in & route march or battalion parade. 

The whole of the afternoon is free to do as we like. Lunch is 12.30 & dinner 6.0 pm. The night is free The one mania in this battalion is football & it is pitiable to see grown men, pretending to be children & with minds incapable of grasping the larger ideals & so degenerate in a eager childish way to amuse themselves with something that cannot interest them. 

The billets are arranged as artistically as possible as marks are awarded to each company & everyone save the diggers simulate keenness Owing to intervention of my company commander Major Carr I manage to get two suits underwear & towel from Baths. After dinner

I have no billet get alloted & doss again with “B" Coy.
Entry.23:
To day after inspection of billet Capt Grace & I look for a logement. First house there is none but when it is discovered that I speak French they immediately disorganise the household to give me a room but as room contains 2 double beds & I require only one I do not take it. 

This morning I met an old wealthy Frenchmen who was quite excited when he found I could speak French & wants me to meet his wife. After lunch I meet interpreter with the Sphinx badge & we proceed to sundry billets all of whom have rooms but no beds some are too far away to suit my fancy. 

However I find one which is very far away (7 minutes) but quite comfy. 

Here also my ability to 
read
 speak French makes me at home with the family & the old lady put the room in order & a warm 
water bottle
 brick in the bed & I am set as the diggers say. The interpreter is an uncouth kind of individual whose

42

knowledge of English is very limited. At one place he knocked & when answered make no reply. Then knocked again & the chap called out is that the Chinese. He merely replied it is not the Chinese but no further information. However the billet he has found me is quite comfy.
Entry.24:
I am orderly officer for company today as R Young is off to Chepy. The duties are nil save that you are present at meals Afternoon write up diary & at night have 3 officers for 34th Bn to dinner Capt Gilder & 2 others. 

On return to billet find madame waiting for me with a packet of Creamola which she asks me to translate into French for her so that she can use it & is very grateful when I do it. I talk with them re New Caledonia and other matters till 11 pm.

When I said NC people wished English flag because it would make them rich the old chap said Riches are not all it is patriotism love of country which counts.
Entry.25:
Usual routine with the exception there is an inspection by some general & everything must be in apple pie order. 

The battalion parade which consists of forming up in lines of companies, 
wheeling
 moving to right in fours – followed by a wheel & a march past in column of coys clearing to left & advancing in line in review order rear rank in front. This is what I mean when I enter up that there is a battalion parade of the usual order.

The afternoon I spent with my diary & at night we are entertaining guests at dinner English officers from Chinese labour camp near by. They are late in arriving. Mess is to utmost capacity. We have a merry dinner with plenty of whisky & port. The party Lt Childs, Bird, Capt Hollands are soon happy & evening is a great success 

 on which on arriving the other day he had driven into the mess & get home about 1.30 am only to find lady has locked me out. However I wake up Redfern & get in through his window.
Entry.26:
Usual routine only a route march under Dixon the battalion as a whole

44

taking part. We march out to Hocquelus a straggling little hamlet with entrenched houses & picturesque tree edged pool in middle of verdant paddocks. 

Afternoon diary. It is tedious work this recording of events but its now nearly up to date. I have not written it up since 27/12/18 when I received orders to move & these 44 pages have been an effort especially as it is some time since the events happened & there are many impressions & events that I have left out.
Entry.27:
Orderly officer to day & in honour of the event the sky is clear & sun bright while the ground & hedges are white with frost. Even the ground mud is frozen. Perhaps my ill luck has turned at last. I visit every part where battalion is billeted & often climb up ladders into lofts or wander thro orchards now destitute of leaves along some winding track to the billets. 

All the cooking is done on the travelling kitchens which are detached & put on ground under cover. Scotson has kindly offered me the use of his billet which has a stove in it. This is not the first

kindly action for which I am indebted to him. 

At last my diary is up to date & I am thankful
Entry.28: This day we hear from Colonel in an address to a muster parade in this grand place the scheme of demobilisation & during afternoon I wash & have a wash in the shower which consist of 5 holes in a pipe. However it is something. Scotson has gone & I am unable to get a fire alright so freeze while my washing remains wet.
Entry.29:
Usual routine – afternoon Scotson room in warm sunshine. The country is delightful when the sun is shining. This is now late in January & there has been no sign of snow as yet. 

The style of house architecture is curious & involves a large expenditure of The back of house is always in front & often obscures a pretty building. The rear of house is always a garden enclosed with a strong high brick wall. 

Outside the wall of 19 de de Villiers The dead & tangled limbs of trees among which birds are already beginning to twitter & when sun 

46

strikes across this dead forest it lightens up the shade & the effect of sunshine & sombre shadow lends enhancement to the view especially in the early morning when the air is brisk & clear & the noisy clamour of this rustic village does not on the of peace & silence. 

The orchard is surrounded by a hedge of tall trees now leafless but soon to break into a glory of green with kiss of spring. While around the inside of the garden trees have been trained & boughs straightened till they run parallel to ground which when in leaf must enhance the scene. In one place B Coy men. These trees are trained as fence & form a roofless verandah.
Entry.30:
Battalion baths this morning & then nothing for next 7 day. 

Am leaving De Villiers to day & go to mess building. is taking over my billet. A slight fall of snow last night but not much. Weather is not unbearably cold so far I have not worn an overcoat. Air is keen especially on face but otherwise sharp brisk or exhilarating is the best term to apply to weather. The last few days have been all sunny day though to get any warmth from sun you must get into a corner. 

Tonight

I attended a lecture on cattle raising & on the way up noticed that among the villagers loves old story is still young & many are the couples (always villagers) who arm round waist walk along this road which is not troubled with street Camps. 

Today I have received an issue of tunic, trousers, puttees & boots. The trousers want altering & the boots dont fit but what does it matter.
Entry.31:
Muster parade again this morning & some more information re demobilisation. I am among the last to leave as it does not interest me moreover yesterday Redfern forwarded a request for Paris University. 

This morning I have commenced to study & am taking the course in agricultural subjects this morning subject being bee farming. This afternoon wrote up diary & loafed. 

Last night I moved my billet into mess quarters M. Boulanger on going home about 10 found M. & Mde drinking vinblanc (or point blank as the diggers call it) with Young & Grace with the lamp out & about 9 candles on a candlebras illuminating the room. 

One thing very noticeable here is the enormous amount of manual labour done by the women even ploughing. Driving lorries often with a big lump of a young man selling

48

in waggons is common sight. The result of this seems a premature ageing of the womenfolk & the spoliation of their beauty & figure. 

The one great lesson that an outsider can learn in this country is that wealth is not the source of happiness. The people here live in absolute poverty & without any of the conveniences necessary to us yet they are happy & contented beyond our visions of happiness. Wealth indeed has little power here to produce happiness as in our & is not regarded or sought after
Entry.32:
This morning lecture on diseases of poultry & then route march to . Then precedence list is issued. I am at bottom Then to Scotson room & remain there till dinner time Expect there will be snow to night It is very cold & the water in streets has now been frozen for several entire days 

The method of pruning fruit trees here is peculiar The idea seems to be to obtain a supply of firewood for winter otherwise the trees would not be touched. The implement used is a butchers cleaver & no saw. Limbs are topped off ad lib & collected for firewood. If we created trees like this in Australia they would all die but here thanks to a cold climate which freezes sap & a

plentiful supply of rain in summer this hacking seems to do little harm. Trees are never pruned for convenience of picking the fruit. Walk in walled garden with Omar
Entry.33: Bee farming again. Carr back – route march Day is bitter cold & no sun – & low-lying mist hangs over the face of the landscape. The air has that wonderful silence that only the country knows. Expect snow tonight. Went for a long walk through the inky blackness which only allows you to see the green outlines of the elms against the sky & the general direction of the road.
Entry.34:
Sunday & anniversary day & it has dawned with a stillness that is oppressive & somehow ominous. On opening the window the whole ground, trees, roofs etc is covered with the whitest of mantles – driven snow. On every spot that will hold it, on every little twig & bud it has lodged & when to this scene of whiteness the church chimes ring out it reminds one of those old time Christmas cards that aunty used to send from England 

Sunday morning it is & this festival of the Christian years gives the only touch of sadness for the women on their way to 

50

church are in their best attire which also too often is deep black & flowing veils a silent reminder of the aftermath of war. & in strange contrast to the whiteness around though the snow which seems to command respect for their sorrows.
Entry.35: Went to Chepy our CM asked to be instructed walked out & back. Met Hutchings. Heavy fall of snow, went out in it & reached Scotson like Father Christmas covered in snow. The fall is very heavy. Snow forms an excellent method of catching a drink. Yarn with Scotson re his visit & he promises to give me some shells
Entry.36: Snow ball fighting in mess & when on way to company men lining both sides of roads behind hedges. Then I march to Hocquelus which was a snowball fight en route & snowball battle during rest time. In afternoon chatted with Scotson & then dinner sit round fire which we have at last in our mess room & then bed
Entry.37:
Battalion parade & search for culprit who had under threat of revolver

had robbed a café of 350 fr. By no means so far have located thieves though to day I heard a rumour that some of my effects have reached this battalion so probably thief is same.

The parade today was over as parade ground covered in snow. Five new officers reported in to day & I am now transferred from No 2 to No 1 platoon. Scotson left this morning detailed for cadre duty at AIBD.
Entry.38:
Usual routine has gone to C Coy. Route march this morning was a glida The snow still remains on ground & the roads are frozen hard making it impossible to walk without slipping. The iron shod heels of issue boots greatly aid this process. Days are very cold & the snow lends a sameness that tires – is already becoming tiresome.

This night my book & razor arrived from Mr Alcock – the book being opened.
Entry.39:
Orderly officer to day & went rounds with Coghill & then have the morning off to myself till 3.15 when guard mounts an elaborate process when a band of 25 performers marches up street to Place to . Thence also come 

52

9 men 1 cpl which constitute the guard & for whom all this paraphernalia takes place. These four men are inspected by Ord. officer & the band lead them down the street accompanied on each side pass near by the awe strucken populace who do not seem to know what to make of these English
Entry.40:
Murder of woman in estaminet – Carr parade on a no parade day – light fall of snow – reply to my application for Paris – fill in 540 Form – row with Chinese at before dinner – snow falling all the afternoon – fine sleet – like drizzling rain only it falls much slower – 

Most of the trees & walls have icicles on them as the cold is intense – nevertheless I have not felt the need of our overcoat so far though chilblains are showing on my hands & I have some severe ones on the little toe of left foot.
Entry.42:
Snow still on ground, chilblains have taken possession of my hand & I have lost use of little

finger on the right hand. Dr has given me some treatment. tabs & codene on hand. Hand pained so much during night that sleep was impossible.
Entry.43:
At 9 am I am detailed to defend one of my old men who was the sole occupant of the house in which an old lady aged 65 was strangled, stabbed & all her cash taken. I spend the morning visiting the scene of the murder where I meet the French detective in charge of the case & the relatives who are very aimable & give us wine & coffee. The afternoon is set apart for an enquiry which does not take place. 

In the evening I meet Arch Monleith & we walk a long way out to talk of sheep farming & then returned with my chillblains. Have received news of my stolen kit today – Have broken pen – Obtained C.O. approval for Paris
Entry.44:
Snowing all the morning – a fine baby snow Ground is soon covered – am detailed to adjust a claim for 300 fr re a fence burned by our company. At midday am detailed to report as Divisional Claims Officers to OISEMENT. This is some of Carrs doing though he refused to admit

54

it. However on seeing Redfern I find CO has cancelled order & said that I was not available so thus far I do not know whether I am going or not at present. Snow is still falling

Tonight received word from de Vere that order was temporarily suspended & that I was to go to Brigade with Thomas as Brigade Claims Officer but that in meantime I stand by. After this I attended a lecture on New Guinea & heard that it rains 269 day in year & averages 1 in per day – that place is full of malaria, crocodiles alligators & cannibals – that natives save 3 tribes are treacherous. Just a nice place to avoid I should think
Entry.45:
No news through to day re transfer – so am sitting still – refusing to attend parades or do anything for the company Redfern & have received sudden orders to sail for Australia to day 

Have seen the post red robin today Generally there are plenty of chaffinch but no robins. Just now the accumulated snow on the roof became dislodged & tons of snow fell on to ground, Pity help anyone caught below they would have a rather rough time of it Went for a walk after dinner 

The whiteness of the road & the high bank 

on either side which seem like white walls of sandbags crowned with hedges of white, together with the tall avenues of elms, with their thick trunk & stately high at the top of which the branches, lopped off everywhere else meet like the arches in the aisle of a church only ever so much loftier – All these combined with an uncanny calmness cannot but impress itself on ones memory with a vividness that will not easily fade.

Every night I take a walk for the quiet beauty of these sepulchral nights appeals more to me than the sordid & silly games of cards & other forms of amusement which men of little intellect employ for fear they might be alone with their thoughts if indeed they possessed any for ever so short a time.
Entry.46: Still no news of my transfer. Redfern is back this morning. Usual routine snow has become frozen & crunches everwhere under your feet. Afternoon Meeken cut my hair, burnt my forehead & skinned my neck for 2f.50. Sun is out to day but there is no warmth in it.
Entry.47:
Day is bitterly cold – snow is frozen on ground & wind has sprung up which cuts the face off you. The ears tingle then pain & then seem frozen. 

To day I accompany C.O. on his rounds & a difficult job it is on the frozen ground to keep from falling. In fact early this morning I measured my length The hot water which the orderly brought to my bed had a thick coating of ice over it at 11 am. I had left window open The window panes are all frozen & when I scrap the front off panes it falls as snow in room & remains there all day which shows that the room is not a hot house & you’d prefer this to sitting near a fire with the rest of the officers.
Entry.48:
Still bitterly cold. Everything is still in the grip of the snow. A new beauty is given to the old ramshackle buildings & sheds which constitute a French home for they are boldly marked out in spotless white. On the trees the effect is even more beautiful resembling a fairy forest of silver. The ground is still of unsullied white & every branch & stem is picked out in firm white lines tapering away like gossamer on each slender stem. This

beautiful picture is some compensation for the discomfort of the cold & the inconvenience of the frozen road dangerous alike to man & beast which will assuredly follow. The washing jug in my room once full of water is now one frozen block of about 18 inches thickness

Today I am moody & full of fancies reflecting much on the problems of this passing show called life but paying little heed to the future, trying to explain to myself where truths end & fancies begin or what we think are fancies are not sometimes real truths. For long is the road of life & who knows what awaits us ere we see its end.

Now we are surrounded by mysteries, mysteries of blood, of inherited spirit, of this world generally in which it is probable we are descended from quite a few common ancestors. And beyond these are other mysteries of the measureless universe to which we belong that may be exercising their strong & secret influences upon us as perhaps they have done for millions of years in the infinite whence we came & whither we go.

58
Entry.49:
No snow fell last night but it is bitterly cold. I shaved in warm water & left my razor on table. Returning in half an hour I found the razor parts frozen together & hard to detach. This will give some idea how cold the room is & I dont leave the windows open. 

The roads this morning are impossible as they are frozen hard. Even the sun cannot thaw them The inhabitants are spraying soil over some parts but this is only in a very few places. My chilblains on my left foot are now confining me to my rooms compulsorily & not by choice as heretofore.
Entry.50:
Had a warm bath last night in a room in which the standing water froze & the windows were encrusted with ice Washing is done in detachment. First head & face & these are dried – then body – then legs & feet. After which I roll into bed. 

This morning Carr is ill & stay in bed all day. Weather is as cold as before. In addition to agricultural classes I am now attending for one week 9 to noon & 2 to 4 pm each day. Chilblains are deadly

better to day. 

Jackson has gone to Abbeville & wanted me to accompany him in spite of my monetary position as I would be his guest – the first kindness I have had shown to me in this mess among the ill mannered & uncongenial beasts known as officers Their names are Carr, Lyne, Henry, Young, Sheehan, Jackson & Clifton. Grace has gone to C “Coy" The few make the room disagreeable & I spent most of my time in my room, writing up diary, learning French or studying environs of Paris where if my application is successful I will spend many happy days although it would be more profitable if I went to farm at Sutton Veny. To day I received my pay book
Entry.51: Am now officially claims officer for the battalion & investigate 2 glass windows broken on Place. Then usual routine
Entry.52:
In course of investigating dammage to fence I go to ordinance camp – meet & have a then luncheon with Wardilore Then we make a party. Visit – (Wardilore enters by windows) visit upstairs take café au rhum – then to

60

 & seen march then to Café Lion d’or then leave Childs & Lindlay & I continue – visit one of Childs café & do not find it interesting – then pass 4 faces then to end of village & return – knocking on window. Terise Richard 48 Rue St Gilles Abbeville then epicure, then café then home to dinner at Chinese camp. This is my first day out in Fresseneville.
Entry.53: Much elation at fact that I have returned back to mess & queries asked what happened & envy when I told my story. Internal combustion class this morning Then claims in afternoon –
Entry.54:
Made a trip to DORE Capt Saunders this morning on OS waggon which had forgotten to order & for which we had to send a mounted messenger. Arrived at Chinese camp saw Childs proceeding across road & went along & picked up wire & returned with Jackson made a tour of cemetery & then home. 

Have received news to day that I am going to Rouen on 2/3/19 & I think my Paris application may be through by then & I hope I shall see the last of the set of alleged officers
Entry.55: Rain all day long. I have an appointment with Lindlay to go for a walk & a promise to met some friends. True to my promise I trudge along through rain & slush to Chinese Camp only to find that Lindlay has been ordered to Calais quite suddenly that morning. So I postpone my walk & yarn with some retired public house keeper & listen to his career & then take afternoon tea & return to camp.
Entry.56: Another claim has come in & I interview several ladies M. Callipe wife. He is out I make an appointment with all the witnesses for to morrow at 1.15 not knowing that I will be miles away.
Entry.57:
Am orderly officer but on reporting to B.OR am relieved & ordered to stand by for Staff Captain who wants to see me at 11 he comes along & says that I will accompany him & Lt Thomas to Gamaches & then Blangy to adjust some claims I get into big motor lorry & travelling is not of the best class. In car I meet Nowland

62

& an interpreter. 

We proceed over the flat country beyond to Hocquelus & then over more flat country till we enter a wood thro which the road winds downward to Gamaches. Here we descend & decide to dine here but have to mass our money to see if we have sufficient for dinner & on finding that we have interpreter books a dinner at Hotel St Pierre.

We then visit Mairie & secretariat at his private house crossing the Place now filled with rows of limbers for Gamaches is the area of the machine gun battalion until recently commanded by Blacklow

We pass a church in very florid style in Rue de la Gore & interview claimants. Then dinner & an excellent meal it was. 2 boule of cider-sauterne & red wine & cheese. – hor d’euvre, fish, culled in cost 8 fr in all. In my present state my finances would not stand the strain of this position

Reclimbing into our grand motor we proceeded to Blangy where I met Brissenden & also Biddulph whom I took for Robinson 1st Bn Am afraid that I will be let in for this job. We take afternoon tea & after buzzing about with heads set off again for home

Pass an ancient chateau similar in architecture to one here only bigger situated in a valley with its gate over which is a gold crest, running up hill to road. Behind on the hill loom the immense forest of Eu once the domain of the Prince Imperial who mortgaged it & the

French govt bought all the equity for £11,000,000 It is said that over £1,000,000 of limber has been taken out of it since war & yet you cannot see where it has been. Forest abounds in deer & boar. Arrived home 5.30 pm not dark till about 6.15 pm.
Entry.58:
Men put up fence – met a frenchman who takes me home & gives me some of the finest cider I have drunk. We put away two bottles. 

Received Aust mail to day & send £10 to my account in London which is unworkable at present time owing to small amount reposing there. 

To night mess gave a farewell dinner to Henry. Carr was absent Dinner was the boys farewell & an excellent turn out it was. Most of the officers were chequered especially the Lyne who bibation made him an excellent & loquacious president. Toasts were numerous. Carr was drunk with empty glass. Then the for which the boys were admitted from the kitchen. Then M. & Mde then La France, Les Allies et others. M. produced cigars which subsequently steals. Lyne & his orderly are too drunk to go home so I assisted by Henry see them home & I put Lyne to bed. Sheehan is dragged home by Clifton & Jackson.

64
Entry.59:
Kitchen staff this morning gives as a meal though they dismissed as from last night. Young is absent & is paraded Lyne will be to-morrow. Jackson & I go to Abbeville as I have today drawn my first pay this year but alas it is all mortgaged & the next few will also be 

At Abbeville make certain purchases try to go up the tower of Church see Parc Boulon, look for Bois sur Scardon then House of Francois premier; then visit ship & invited to dine at Georgette Dumonts 8 Place Cour du Ponthieu 8 but do not. Then home again
Entry.60:
Am orderly officer again. Then visit M Calippe & make an appointment at 1.15 pm & keep it & am surrounded by small crowds of men women & girls all wanting to explain at once. I beat the old chap down

Then visit Dr for my cold is increasing & then pay for the remittance of which will leave to morrow. Then to room Mess is now deserted by all officers. Lyne was paraded to day & brought up a lot of complaints against Carr.
Entry.62:
Went to Chinese camp this afternoon to tell Capt Grice (West Susssex) that we would be up to dinner on Tuesday & not Monday & to go for a walk with him. He is out so I walk over to Dargnies passing Heyman & another officer on the way. 

Dargnies is a small village in the wood as straggling as most villages. Here I saw a man in a little carts drawn by two dogs & moving much faster than I could run. He seemed unusual as all the villagers stopped to look at him. Thence I went on to Woincourt through the village & home again.
Entry.63: Usual routine. Lecture on Australia affair – frightened boy –
Entry.64:
Intended to ride with major to Blangy this afternoon but owing to some officer coming he could not go but lent me his horse & together with Clifford & the galloper we set out for 

66

Unfortunately by taking a wrong turning we went in an exactly opposite direction & found ourselves at Valines Returning to Fressenville we went as far as Freville where we went to Escarbotin. Had a couple of Rhum & coffee at Cafe des voyageurs then returned to camp.

Immediately I had to leave to keep my appointment with the Chinese officers. I went along without Jackson who could not come. After dinner adjourned to Grices billet & went serenaded by Childs, Bird & Petre. Capts Wardilove & Wright joined us & we had a most interesting discussion re Mexico & China at same time smoking excellent cigars & punctuating all speeches with nips of whisky. 

I arrive home about 12.30 pm after a very pleasant evening & having made arrangements with Grice for a trip to morrow
Entry.65:
This afternoon we caught the 3.30 train to Eu. The pic describes place better than diary. Went into Cafe de Hesdin Mde Delmoitte, Villa Les Fumlaux, onival par ault Somme had rum & coffee quite a usual ten to Church & Gateau, then to Rue a 
river
 street with a river in the centre – then to College St Agnes & old city walls. Then took train to Le

Treport, walked to end of town & along pier Views along coast are fine & the near cliffs are overwhelming see pic. The Casino is closed as hospital but last man is leaving to morrow Walked along Plage & over to funicular the railway which goes up & through the cliff to the old Hotel Trianon now No 3 General Hospital. 

Retracing our steps we cross the bridge & to Railway Station see pic then back to Hotel des Baises. After this we walked up & down street & then as we had a better chance of catching a goods train from Eu commenced to walk back there & uncomfortable it was as it was raining. I had Jacksons trench coat & the 4 KM were soon covered. 

On arrival at station the lad informed us none too civilly that there were no goods trains & that we must wait till 4.40 am to morrow morning. We go along to Hotel de La Gore & it is complet. We then followed woman who is looking for a room & are finally given a room (5 fr) at Hotel de Commerce where Augustine lives & slept or half slept till 4 am when we arose & caught train arriving home at 6 am. (Mde.
Entry.66:
Turned in at 6 am & rose 8.40 am feeling quite refreshed & none the worse for nights outing & went on duty as orderly officer, arriving

68

at HQ 10 minutes late was told that Major wanted to see me. This put the wind up & more when on asking for CO orderly asked me if I had had my breakfast. I thought CO had got to know that I had been away without leave. However it was to act as interpreter. One of our men being accused of stealing from train – the same who had rushed into mess previous night – & french police wished to interrogate him – 

After this went on duty as orderly officer. Sky is peculiar a greenish yellow & we hurry off guard in fear of hail but none came.
Entry.67: has interfered & stopped my going to Rouen but Redfern rights matter. Get Melhuish for an orderly – & await end of day but have not yet asked permission to go & may be thrown back till Sunday yet.
Entry.68:
Received permission to start & got away by 11.15 train Little Melhuish is almost invisible with his kit 3 blankets, helmet rifle & my pack He reminds of the old cartoon in Punch of the father who would only hear his sons voice out of the mass of material in front of him.

Arrived in Abbeville Melhuish gets rid of baggage & I slip-along to club with Capt R in the Chinese camp a missionary from China & therefore somewhat of a contrast with your 

humble servant. During dinner Crudge comes in & he & I spend the afternoon together walking along the banks of the Scardon for a long way & return to town passing on way a very old church situated on a hill very much above the street level.

We then tried to ascend to Lower of St Wulfram but found permission has been barred by the English authorities who always seem to be interfering where interference is least justified. Then finished up at Elat where we dined 4 fr. Elsewhere in town dinner costs 10 to 30 fr. These EFC are the salvation of officers who otherwise would have less money than they have now.

After dinner I visited 43 Rue de la Caseine looking for Crudge & after to Green shutters but he was not in either. I visited Bar of Hotel de la France & had coffee though there is no dancing here to night as is usual. Finally at about 12.30 am I went to Club & was given a bed (2 fr) in the long dormitory called annexe.
Entry.69:
Have made arrangement to meet Melhuish at 10 am. I rise fairly late being Sunday have finished breakfast by 9.30 & spend the time upstairs & talk to a WAAC who is cleaning up the room. I tell her that I must meet someone at 10 & she laughs outright & tells me that it

70

was 10 am an hour ago as the daylight saving scheme is always in force here & all clocks were put forward one hour last night. I then hurry out find Melhuish & away we start for Dev. Wing which after walking every inch of the way we reach just after noon.

I dine here get papers but owing to delays cannot get away in time to catch 2 pm train so must rest to night in Abbeville though there is nothing more to see & I have no friends. However I chum up with some English chap & after tea go for a walk. He leaves me early to visit two friends Leoni et Marie 8 & I return to sleep. To morrow I must rise at 5 as train leaves at 6.7 am.
Entry.70:
Roused myself at 5 am – dressed & shaved & as I was setting off found that I might have had breakfast had I desired & also that train left 6.7 am & not 6.20 as RTO had endorsed my movement order. However I had made my dispositions well ahead of time & caught train together with orderly. 

In train met two Tank Corps officers & landed in Amien at 8 am. We all three went along to Hotel de Paris for breakfast The other hotel charged these officers 30 fr a piece for dinner on a previous occasion (Hotel de l’Univers). We had an

omelette & coffee. Opposite a lady with her mother spoke English to us notably while everyone seemed in a desperate hurry & rattled plates & ran away from tables after the waitress to hurry up their . 

We walked up Rue de & visited Cathedral a magnificent structure the finest I have seen seeming all space. A shell has entered roof missed pillars & smashed a named tile on floor & failed to explode a miraculous escape for the building. The windows are the most glorious mass of colours & symmetry that I have seen & this pic do not do them justice. In rear of building is statue of Peter the Hermit 

Alongside of Cathedral is Palais de Justice much sprinkled with the effects of shrapnel fire. I then leave my friends & commence a tour of the town along the Boulevards commencing with Belfort, past the statues of illustrations then to Cirque a municipal theatre now badly damaged by shell fire see pic. Opposite is Hospital of St Vincent badly damaged by shell fire. 

I then visited the promenade de la Hotore, a raised road flanked on either side by a triple row of trees. The bassin now a long dry field shows the marks of shells holes by which the Germans ranged gradually creeping up till they had

72

range of adjoining factory when they deflected & smashed it to pieces. In centre of field is large pools 15 ft in diameter at regular intervals similarly ranged & for the same purpose. 

I continued on till I reached the Post D’Aval then to Garden des Plantes – where whole glasshouses are devoted to the culture of our common geraniums. Here rain came on & as I had no coat I took shelter with the gardeners & told them all about the great size of our farms.

Then I wander down down & meet a NZ Captain who is visited a Mde Hautecoeur 21 Rue de & after we dine at a tea room 

I then go to Railway station & find that my train is starting almost immediately & that I must go in it or wait till 6 am to morrow all trains seem to leave at unholy early hours. There is no other alternate so we go on board leaving at 5-40 pm
