On we go through undulating country fringed on limits with hills or forest reminding me of eastern coast near Poya. The whole country is intersected with filled in trenches & dugouts now of no use but once filled with an importance far beyond their present innocent look. 

Night comes & finally at 11.23 pm we land at Rouen & find ourselves stranded the orderly is alright as there is a rest camp for him But for officers none

I find myself in company with a Scotch machine gunner named Johnston. He is not anxious to pay for room & we look for hostel. In search I find a large house well lit up & door open I go in but can find no one In one room I find the unfinished meal of some people & sit down & have a meal on what is left Scoty is afraid to enter & I bring him out some bread & cheese. 

This is all I have to eat since the omelettes this morning as I intended to dine in Amien but proposes etc. At last weary of looking for home we go to Hotel d’Angleterre get a room & a couple of bottles of beer & sit up till 1.30 am yarning.
Entry.71:
This morning we rise late & breakfast at the Club. Then catch No 9 for base du Nord to pick up the batmen. Then No 6 train to Quevilly. Here we find No 6 Vet Hospital & report to orderly room then on to school to Major McColl & Capt MacLennon who is adjutant. The school comprises Cpt Richards, Capt Shaw – Middlesex, Lt Johnston MG, Lt Hall – Manchester, Lt Young (Cameronian, Lt Shelton XV. KH., Lt Mansell RFS ()

The morning is spent in fixing up quarters & then as afternoon is free

74

I go into Hotel de’Angleterre with Young who has left his things there. We then adjourn to club & met McCartney & More. Then visit Braserie de l’Opera & American Bar back in Rue de Charettes. Then Apollo & Hotel de Paris where we left the others & visited Stephanies Rue de Grosse Horloge opp Hotel du Nord & finally after many adventures walk home arriving here about 2.30 am. To day I draw all available cash & by end of night had spent it all.
Entry.72:
As very few of the 37 expected have arrived the course is postponed one day to await their probable arrival & Young & I again set off for town. Afternoon tea at Club bring Lt Morton 3rd Bn to me & he joins our company: I meet Gabrielle Petit & then go home to dinner with Morton at his billet. 

The old man is very ill. I yarned & he has invited to dine with him. We return to our rendez-vous at 8 pm at St Ouen & then we went to the Apollo a variety theatre with hideous painted actresses who sang English songs in French & throughout the whole performance a modernly dressed man & woman persisted their modern allure contrasting strangely with the costumes say of ancient Egypt in a scene from Cleopatra or the tights of ballet dancers. The boxes here

are little square apartments with sides about 3 ft high & not your own as any comer may be run into them. I left at the interval & found last tram had gone & had to walk home
Entry.73:
School has commenced today & the routine is lectures 8-12 with ½ hour intervals & 2 to 3 pm rest of day is free to ourselves. 

Went down town this evening & visited & climbed Tranbordeur & then went to St Ouen a beautiful Gothic church – we walked round the clerestory & viewed church from various points There are 3 beautiful rose window. We then mounted to the roof climbed around it & then breaking down the door that obstructed us we went to the highest part of the tower – a dangerous thing to do as masonry is not safe here. The tops of the spires seemed to me remarkably unsafe & a good wind should blow over the crowning monuments. In future I shall keep away from churches in case they should fall down. 

We then visited the Lower where Joan of Arc was imprisoned while awaiting trial & the actual spot where she was burned Then I wandered among the back streets & find that Rouen is a centre of much architectural beauty. The old crooked & blind streets running into each

76

other are rich with old relic. In one place I found the wall of an old 
building
 church has been used as the supporting wall of a modern private dwelling.
Entry.74: Lectures as usual – went down to Rouen now a daily practice with me & visited American Bar & played billiards
Entry.75:
Saturday afternoon is free & I devoted it to sight seeing. Visited the Churches of St Patrice with some magnificent old stained windows. Then went on to St Godards & thence to Palace de Justice a magnificent structure. 

Some of the actual chairs put here by Louis XIV still remain in same place. The old meeting room of Parliament of Normandy is same the relief on the oak roof touched with gold is 1 ½ metres in depth & looks fine. The grills show a finish that nowaday we would slur but they were artists in those days & worked for arts sake. This room has a beautiful carving of Christ so beautiful that when all traces of religion were removed from halls of Justice this one was left because it was too beautiful to spoil & so this remains the only

religious symbol in any court in France. We then entered Salle de Pas Perdu & Court of Appeal. On a back street we stumbled on the remnant of an old castle destroyed in about 1100 AD & this piece still persists.
Entry.76: This is Sunday & we have been told that there will be lectures rather unusual & unnecessary we think but orders are orders I intended to go out to day but rain has set in & I do not move out at all
Entry.77:
This vet Hospital has been the disposing centre for army horses for some time past & horses are regularly offered for sale Mon & Fridays. The mules average about 700 fr & the horse 1300 to 1400 Many people advocate that these horses should not be sold to french as they do not know how to treat an animal. 

We saw two girls here to day with their father & brought them & their male friends into mess where we had some dancing & some little conversation The girls are awfully jolly Another little girl who was here & who speaks English well has herself in

78

to day on behalf on her father 50,000 fr.
Entry.78: Usual routine – met Behrend – visited Le ontaint so Marie et Musée.
Entry.79: Again in Rouen – visited various places of no particular interest but quaint – address on Posis 130 Rue de Faubourg St Denis Sonia visited Hotel de la Bourse. I am awfully short of cash & live from hand to mouth. In a way I am sorry I came here for it is eating up my cash & I am always at my wits end to know where to get it. I have decided not to partake of any jollity till I have something in hand
Entry.80: A lecture is being delivered to night by Richards & so no one can go to Rouen ordinary routine
Entry.81:
Usual lecture – day again to day & the two girls came again Their escort wanted to shout us all drink & finally we arrange to meet them tomorrow

when they will have their horses & if we cannot find horses they will dismount & we can go for a walk. To day I am orderly officer & so cannot go out
Entry.82: Rain to day & stayed in all day intending to spend all my available cash tomorrow
Entry.83:
Lectures as usual this morning & as it is raining our plans for the afternoon are doubtful but Mansell & I decide to go & as it is raining I take Mansells trench coat. 

We catch the little boat “Elan" see pic & away we swing down river with current we pass for some time through the shipping adjoining the port & then into more open country of manufacturing kind – Then we pass long islands now only a few feet above the level of the Seine which is still in flood. Most of the islands have one or two houses most of them abandoned as a few days ago the islands must have been 2 or 3 ft under water 

On right side we pass many more or less inviting old Chateaux often closed & in many cases without any attempt to beautiful the front though this is not true in every case. Here we pass enormous chalk cliffs & these

80

have been honeycombed to 
give
 make a house in the rock the only sign that a house exists is the barred windows. These chalks often come away in large land sides so should not like living under them though in some cases the village is built under them

Further along the river opens out into a wide pastoral & agricultural country running up to forest clad hills. On a dominating part of the ridge looms up the ruins of the castle of who in & about 1070 prodeused all the & cruelty of hell here. The ruins which I did not visit on this trip seems to have been restored.

The villages passed include Croisset, Val de Haye? sahens, & La Boulle a pretty little village nestling beneath perpendicular chalk cliffs. The church has a landing place for almost at its door & half the town is separated from riverbank by a narrow street only. In the other parts the streets are so narrow that it would be absolutely impossible for 2 carts to pass & if one cart is in the street the other must back to the next cross street.

The spot is very pretty & I will certainly make another trip there. The day was not suitable and was very cold & we were nearly frozen by the time we arrived back. The journey took 1 ½ hrs down & 2 hours back. 

On arrival in town we went to Club & dined & then

went off to Opera though everyone told us we could never get in. However a knowledge of French is handy & things worked well & we got an excellent seat – right in centre of house. 

The theatre is a fine spacious building though one has to mount a flight of stairs to reach even the ground floor. There is no promenoir & one must go outside to smoke. The entrance seemed dirty & draughty & the passage & rooms outside the theatre itself cramped one to the extent of being uncomfortable. The interior is large & luminously gilded the roof pointed with figures in the sky & looks real while the chandelier of electric lights is gorgeous. The seating accomodation I should estimate at 2500 about. There are 4 tiers or . 

The play was Faust & excellent it was the artists being imported from Opera at Paris. Huberty () Valentin (Lestelly an excellent voice) Marguerite (Mareille Berthon). The performance was excellent & the 9f 50 was an excellent investment 

In middle we went to Brasserie & picked up Young & Morton gave him a reserved seat After performance concluded we visited Hotel de Paris on & then to Charley Bar in Peace du Vieux Marche & finally picked up the valiant Cameronian & started off for home.
Entry.84:
Usual routine – no lecture in afternoon

as there are about 12 men to be paid & here this takes about 3 hours.
Entry.85:
Have decided to go quiet this week in order to amass cash & have sworn off drink. Lecture to night on Rhodesia which was very interesting. Land abounds in parts & wild animals – land is good but little is agriculturally used cattle raising being the main industry. Fences do not exist. Land is freely given but somehow I dont fancy going there. In fact huge wealth is necessary to make wealth while the climate is not exactly nice for a white woman.

If farm fail you cant hire yourself to next neighbour for manual work is left to the blacks who are given a small piece of land in return for so much labour.
Entry.86: Usual routine – went to town with Mansell.
Entry.87: Usual school with a lecture in evening by Mansell on his air experiences.
Entry.88:
As Mansell has received orders to leave the school decide to go to town, lunch together & go to theatre. As I am orderly officer I cannot go & spent the day in solitude with a fire & a book which I am too sleepy to read. 

At dinner I disclose my real identity to Major McColl & we chat on for some time & write letters. The major is sorry that I am in & wishes he had known & I could have gone – However it suits my purpose to stay in as I have no money & must economise & I get his commiseration
Entry.89:
Lectures cease at 12 noon to day & Mansell Richard & I sail into down into the Museum of antiquities most clerical from old churches with some old armour. One rifle about 10 ft long & a good collection of spurs. 

Thence we visited museum with anotomical castes of neck face hand feet & development of foetus. Then to an Exhibition of painting in the Musée in 
Luxembourg
 Solferino Garden. The painting is put on with trowels & the rooms are not long enough to allow the proper effect to be obtained though some of the awful 

84

daubs contain no merit & would look better at 10 miles than 10 paces. One picture in particular struck my eye a park scene with a couple of ladies seated on a seat & a little girl in the foreward

Thence we went to Club for afternoon tea & then took 16 tram to Bon Secours & visited its church a magnificent structure without though oppressive within & filled with a wonderful style of glass window. They contain figures & those small & yet the colour effect is magnificent. 

Then we went on to Joan of Arc memorial whence a view for miles up & down the river & away in the distance miles away look the green & verdant pastures of Normandie. The visit was worth the vista & I think I shall go there again. 

Thence we retraced our steps Mansell nursing a French baby in the tram & I holding on my knee my other friend an artillery officer about 6 ft high We dined at Club (4 fr) & then to Opera where Mm Carre was playing the main part in Madame Butterfly – the most powerful representation I have seen the singing & the acting were marvellous & I quite lost myself – Tears were in my eyes at times. 

Then to Hotel de Paris for a deep draught of the most delicious beer in town & then the long walk home
Entry.90:
Instead of one of the lectures we had a demonstration & a post mortem on a horse. At the killing of the horse Young who had seen bodies in all stages of decomposition & mutilation in the Somme offensive had to go into the open air for fear of fainting. On same Mansell who flies at heights up to 15,000 feet in bombing raids could not mount steps about 50 ft high the other day because he began to feel & had to come down. 

All the lads have gone to a VAD dance to night but as I dont like VAD & am too old for dancing I do not go.
Entry.91: Am very staid & proper this week & have even renounced drinking so that I may accumulate a little cash for bust up on last night & also I purpose returning via Paris & that costs money. Life is very expensive. Egg even in mess cost 60 centimes Whisky 60c Brandy 90c
Entry.92:
Yesterday I forgot to mention I met in town Germaine & Louise Pegara & had afternoon tea then in a patisserie opposite

86

Place de la Cathedrale & full of reflecting mirrors – They are two very nice girls & I hope to see them again if possible. They are too respectable to be seen with me & we must needs walk on opposite sides – if mother is with them I ignore them Life is funny is it not
Entry.93:
The date today is 14/4/19 & I am therefore trying to write without any memoranda past events & impressions Therefore few of the impressions remain & it is only with difficulty that I can piece the events together & many of this kind is of little interest to anyone even the writer but for the sake of having a complete record I am filling in the days so that the tale may be fully told

This afternoon I met Germaine & we took afternoon tea in a tea shop 44 Rue de la Republique upstairs. There was a VAD & an English officer also. 

Dined tonight at Club 4.50 fr with Young & Johnston & then joining up with Cameron & a so-called Capt J Walker a drunken Aussie whom Cameron was trying to avoid. Walker insisted on tapping everyone on the head with his club & the stewards laughingly put up with it having seen him decorously & solemnly seating himself on the floor some minutes earlier 

On the street he assailled a drunken French civilian. Trying to effect a composure the civvy sees my cane & rushes for it

& then ensues a struggle between myself & the civvy only ended by my allowing him to have the stick which otherwise he might break. After pacifying the french & sending the Aussie away I dispersed crowd & then decided that such an exhibition of Australia must cease & so took him back to his rooms at the Angleterre

Meanwhile I had lost my friends but assuming that I should find them waiting for me at the dance made my way back to Hotel de la Poste & find that one cannot enter without a note of invitation from some one. Young however has got into conversation & into difficulties with a slight & delicately formed girl in a scarlet dress with a 
red
 black domino I am called in as the inevitable interpreter & do it faithfully. A very difficult task with a pretty girl especially as she live over Brasserie St Rue Place Cathedrale 

However we leave about go to Charley’s Bar a dancing cabaret in Market Place at which one gives mysterious knocks & is admitted along a dark lane or channel for it is covered to dancing & bar room. However we do not stay long as place is crowded. 

This is night of & everyone is parading in fancy dress especially the younger element. Leaving Charley Bar we go to Hotel du Nord but find dancing is finished & then go on to 
Café
 Hotel de Paris where we stay for some time & then walk home via No 6 tram road to Casino Rouennaise

88

where there is a grand ball in progress

There are hundred on floor & though fun & amusement is rampant the class is rather below an officers dignity while the air is hot & stuffy & the hot air rising congeals in beads of moisture on the iron walls. Two girls attired in many colours drink the drinks off another table as fast as waiter puts them down but waiter recovers them for the original order Tired we go home & to bed
Entry.95: Whatever I did on these days other than the school lectures has passed my memory & nothing can be recorded
Entry.96:
Lectures in the morning & then in afternoon meet at Brassiere Louise et her mother. Go down a side street & then Louise is detached to find me. Then in train together & pick up Germaine & mother – end of conversation alight at bridge & go to Eden picture show & get ticket alongside of her. She whispers location as she passes & get ticket. As performance does not start till 4.30 pm & it is now three they decide not to wait & I clear off & visit St Maclow a church in flamboyant Gothic style often called the miniature St Ouen & then returned

to Cinema & am beckoned to their staircase but am far away & seat is filled when I arrive & I sit elsewhere. At interval I seek with a rapid message having made arrangements for her next door neighbour to move & I spend next arranging to meet them on Tuesday. 

In evening I go to 
Carmen
 by George Bizet who committed suicide on account of half received success of Carmen. Lafont took Toreador but was not pleasing Don Jose, Ovido Zuinga Roujon, Carmen, Alice Raveau, Micaela Mde Arty all from Opera – Comique The play was staged in 4 acts – Cyar Factory, Tavern of Lilas Pasted, Smugglers retreat in mountain & Cirque de Seville Performance is not nearly so good as last Sunday night.

Next Sunday is Louise a very long piece & a piece which I have just missed seeing several times. After theatre went to Paris Hotel for an hour & then home to Petit Quevilly.
Entry.97: Another day the record of which has passed away from my memory, save that I sent a special pic home as this is the birthday
Entry.98:
Met Louise today & later Germaine in our little tea shop, & then go on to Isaackson & Morton at the Bakeries for dinner with 2 girls

90

whom they have invited down. This is preceded by a concert of Lena Ashwells party & then came the dinner & an excellent one it was Fresh bread is a novelty & much appreciated as our bread is always 4 or 5 days old. After dinner Morton & I saw the girls home. I as far as Bridge & then went to Paris Hotel my usual rendezvous if in town about about midnight.

11-4-19 (Tues)

Intend going to night to Rue St Julien but on arriving at Bakeries am persuaded to go to a fancy dress ball of the “Fragments" as a sundowner & an excellent one I made 

We arrived too late for much dancing but soon enough to receive an insight into the characters of British officers & gentlemen Two (Major Love + 1 other) seize food & champagne off the table & hurry away to cloakroom to gorge & though their eyes were bigger than they abdominal regions they never contemplated sharing it with the only other occupant of the room – Another Colonel came to his pocket got his flask poured a nip to his friends he looked to Isaackson & with a Heres to your drained it off likewise the Colonel & then departed leaving Isaackson thirsty.

Then a member of committee who sends every day to Bakery for fresh bread & got it told Isaackson

he could not find partners as he did not know any one, & so on the night was full of similar incidents. This might be the Englishmans idea of showing what his manners are to Australians for some knew Isaackson but I am inclined to think it is just their natural character & lack of courtesy & knowledge of the elementery rules of politness so unnecessary to selfish natures. 

After this we met the one decent Englishman in the room Twigg & told him he was too good to be an Englishman & we were taking out papers to make him a Naturalised Englishman.
Entry.99: Attended a Masonic meeting in Room 13 Hotel du Nord. Method of examination is slipshop & embarassing. Richards is with me but Isaackson has gone to Paris. Dined with Richards & then went to Brasserie de l’Opera when he left me & I came home.
Entry.100:
This will be almost our last night in camp as school ends tomorrow though passed will not be ready till 7th so we have decided to have a dinner I have invited Isaackson & we arrive

92

late. There are many guests & old mess is very bright & full of hilarity. After dinner drinks go the rounds & all is merry Young is dancing fling & Johnston sing Hamilton is improvising Isaackson has been lucky enough to. Orgie continues far into the night & we finally go to bed about 2 am very early for us.
Entry.101:
This will be the last night that I will have a free leg in this town as I am booked for Opera to morrow night & on Monday I leave for Paris. Richards will go round with me & I am to meet him at Club. 

In afternoon I meet Germaine & we go to Bon Secours & walk along the lands & orchards of Cote de Ste Catherine & then return to town where I leave here in Rue Jeanne d’Arc near Palais de Justice after putting her on the tram (No 12) 

Then to dinner & then Brasserie de l’Opera where I lose Richards & almost decide to go home. However I strike a NZ Captain in street staring idly at a building but really waiting for some one to come out & meet him. I take a walk towards his home & then we decide to go the rounds for the night – 

We go to Paris Hotel & meet Cameron & a New Foundland officers. We then visited Stephanis, Hill 60, Charleys Bar – now overflowing with civilians

then near Hotel du Nord meet a fair haired girl & go with her to Hotel du Palais & have several drinks but do not stay in spite of invitations addressed to me & then to Lloyds diggings in Rue de Champs Naillot off Rue Thierx & slept in a Major’s room, & comfy indeed it was for at the camp we sleep between blankets not of cleanest & not sufficient quantity in a big cold room. 

In morning I shave with Lloyds gear & breakfast on rolls & jam & then to Cathedrale where we intend to hear the music.
Entry.102:
Arrived at Cathedral we find all the music was at 10 oclock mass & so we are too late. We then visit St Ouen for sake of seeing the wonderful reflection in colour of the whole interior of the church in the holy water fount. Fount is a dark marble basin & gives a background for reflection. 

We return to Cathedral where Lloyd meets his friend & I wander off on my own to Bois 
the
 Guillaume which I have some difficulty in finding as the village is named by some name & I stroll into village before I find my mistake. The wood is indeed glorious – a natural forest without any undergrowth which enables the

94

eye to travel among innumerable tree trunks till it becomes tired & bewildered & then dropping down sees a beautiful carpet of russet brown caused by the autumn leaves which winter rains have not rendered sodden & through which are innumerable flowers of many colours white & red predominating & coming through the dead leaves remind one truly of the “Flowers of the Forest". 

Tired I lay down on the inviting brown & drowse for a while only to be disturbed by two youthful lovers whose cares are all their own. The woods have a good few people wandering among the gaunt limbs or reposing in the shade & I left the woods or the country as it is called before the crowd had arrived. 

This is a glorious day of spring like a day in the islands & everyone is out. I return to city & then out on other side opposite Petit Quevilly & above Croisset on slopes of Mt Bidoret where there is a monastery with beautifully wooded grounds even thicker & more natural than the forest. I remain here for some time with a glorious panorama of Rouen at my feet & in no hurry to move. 

Finally I start my now weary legs in motion & start downhill for the tram covered

in dust from every passing car for these roads so beautiful to look upon are damnable in dry weather & every car raises a cloud of dust through which you cannot see for several seconds 

Covered with dust I take train & finally reach Club where I manage to clean myself a little & then dine & hungry indeed I am for I have been feasting on natural beauty & have neglected the 
more
 baser forms of food.

After dinner I meet Morton & go to “Louise" The first two acts are very poor & not all gripping though this may have been due to some extent to imperfect representation but the third act opening with “Depuis le Jour" & reaching in a climax in a duet of adoration of “Paris splendid et –“ is a masterpiece & justifies the wait. The fourth act while good is not on same high tone.

After theatre went to Paris for last time met Madeline also Cameron who wishes to engage me in a salvage case & finally get home about 4 am.
Entry.103:
This morning orderly overslept himself & so missed train. There is another at 4 pm but the objection to catching this is

96

it lands one in Paris at 9.40 pm & it is to difficult to get a room or find one’s way around. A train leaves here at 7 pm & reaches Paris 10.30 pm but this is worse However it means spending night at Quevilly or Paris & I decide for the attractions of Paris.

The mess here is a profitable institution run by base wallowers for their own profit at the expense of the fighting troops. The two officers decide that any profit in the mess must come into their hands & go on ordering whisky right up till last day. All of which will revert to them. I am glad to get away from such a grasping crowd & hope I have seen the last of the A.V.C. 

On way down lorry containing our kits bolts & after an exciting time finally pulls up without smashing anybody or anything other than the reins & the tail boards. As it will mean missing this train if I wait till fresh harness is brought I take my orderly & small kit on in tram & reach Gare Rue Verte – meet Turgy – get an Ordre de Transport for Paris & off we go.

I have the whole carriage to myself as French RTO has cleared out all 2 & 3rd class passengers. We pass over 
Bridge
 Pont des Anglais & circle round town & then swing into Seine valley & follow it stopping at Sotteville

& at St Etienne – exactly opposite St Adrienne. Then where two rivers meet but we are still in full sight of the gully – no hills to cut us off. 

Next Gaillon with its old chateau built in 1000 by Francois I – now used as a prison Next Le Goulet where the river bed is flat on each side & the gradually sloping hills on left side covered with little coloured squares remind one of the Thames while in short time the banks become forest lined on one (left) side & other opens into fields like the upper reaches of the Thames.

Then we pass Vernon with its old Tower erected in 1123 by Henry 1 of England then a Norman duke as well To left we pass ruins of Chateauneuf of Phillip Auguste now no longer new. At Rosny I see the Chateau of Rosny Minister of Henry IV & afterwards the residence of the Duchess of Berry. Next comes Mantes – the pretty – where William I was thrown from his horse & subsequently died. 

Then we pass Possy the birthplace of St Louis & thereafter it is too dark to see anything till Paris is reached. We arrive about 10 pm. My first task is to find a room for the orderly & this I succeed in doing though it costs even in a YMCA () rest house 7 francs for bed & breakfast & then I start off for a canadian hostel in Place D’Iena This I find little difficulty in doing 

98

as Paris is much the same as Sydney I seem to know every street & house as if I had lived here for years. I wonder if I ever did – At anyrate I strolled along to Avenue to Champs Elysees flanked on either side with guns & on the seats many a lover 
of
 from this gay city a strange contrast of love & war. 

But Paris is essentially a city of contrasts in which a dead Past is ever thrusting its 
skull
 hollow eyes on a gay & living Present which smiles to hide the Past. Arrived at I get a room 7 fr & breakfast 3 fr & retire for night. There are two others in the room one of whom is an Australian perhaps I shall see him to morrow. His name is Baker.
Entry.104:
Morn & morn such as Paris loves to clothe herself bright warm sunshine & a sky of blue. I join forces with Baker who agrees to follow my lead – in breakfast room I meet Coghill & am afraid as he is my battalion commander & I am really here without permission. He recognises me & is no longer in command of battalion & I arrange to meet him at 6 pm in order to go to the Opera.

I then walk down to that most spacious square the Place de la Corcorde – now filled with 

with German guns whose days are as effectively over as de Guiltonine who once dominated this once Place de la Revolution. 

The view up to the madelin flanked on Square edge with two similar building is magnificent & pigmies other architecture I have seen & loses it in beauty by its uniformity. In fact uniformity more or less according to some fixed plan seems to be the keynote of their architecture & its effect is to raise the general appearance of city beyond any other city in the world –

There is only one Paris. Looking up the broad Avenue de Champs Elysees 1 ½ miles in length & 400 yds wide crowned at top with the massive Arc di Triomphe or down the other way to those great piles of masonry known as the Louvre whose stupendous proportions numb our sense of architecture & leaves us aghast & awestricken at the wonderful intellects who could construct such works

On other sides is Chamber of Deputies across Pont de la Concorde Crossing Place we enter the Garden de Tuileries with the Allee des Orangers on the right the orange trees being in & some 500 yrs old. Here once stood the Palais de Tuileries burnt by Communards 1871 & now only a garden & lawns remain to mask a spot more closely bound up with the history of France

100

in the closing years of 18th century than any other edifice 

Now we are in the enormous Louvre & in front is the statue of “Quand Meme" & of Gambetta typical of the latent fire of patriotism which has never been absent from this France – a country filled with dirty habits & unsanitary conditions but all of which is burnt white in the fire of its unquenchable patriotism. 

Near by is Palais Royal & Further on we reach Hotel de Ville a renovated replica of the original destroyed in 1871 with numerous little courtyards once the scene of such bloody fighting though now filled with busy people. Behind Hotel de Ville is St Gervais church quite unlike any church I have seen, heavy & squat approached by a flight of steps about 12 ft high. 

Next we reach Place de la Bastille – though no ports of old dreaded prison remains save that a ring of white stones marks the perimeter & on one house is a plan of old fortification. In centre stands the Colonne de Junillet surmounted by a globe on which stands the Genius of Liberty with the torch of civilisation in one hand & the broken chains of slavery in the other while around the column are inscribed the names of those who fell in cause of liberty on 27, 28 & 29 in July 1830 Their names are likewise chronicled in the Pantheon 

Then along the grand Boulevards past place de Visages to

the Peace de la Republique once occupied by a bastion of the old fortifications swept away by Louis XIV & now embellished with a stature of the Republic with three figures Liberty Equality & Fraternity 

Thence I turned into The Boulevards – by streets but hardly sufficient to accommodate the crowds that throng it Passing the Porte St Martin & then Porte St Denis – the latter as dear to my memory from the song & then on through the fashionable Boul de Italiens to Place de l’Opera. 

At end of which stands the Opera House an enormous structure covering nearly 3 acres of ground & costing for building alone £1,460,000. On opposite side of square is a large hotel containing over 1,000 bedroom – 

I then follow on the Boulevarde de la Madeline to the Madeline itself – a building in style of a Roman Temple intended for a Temple of Glory by Nap. 1 – it has no windows being lighted from above & is built entirely of stone. 

So far I have had no luncheon & am becoming tired so proceed back to Hotel passing Palais Royal built by Richelien & after occupied by Anne of Austria & the birthplace of Louis XIV. 

At Hotel, I take off my boots & rest my feet & find a big blister under one of my toes. After about ½ hour we set off for Montmartre via the Metropolitan passing Trocadero on our way. This my first experience of Paris Tube is much more to my taste

102

than the London one for I do not get lost perhaps this is due to my London experience & arrive after after a change at Place D’Anvers where we alight & seek the funiculaire & we are now on the Butte Montmatre whence Henri IV shelled the city & on summit of which is the Basilique du Sacre Coeu the home of which one can mount (260 ft) whence a glorious panorama of Paris can be obtained for the whole city is indeed at your feet. 

Hastily returning to keep my appointment with Coghill. This means waiting on metro station entrance in Place de l’Opera & a splendid insight can be gained of Paris by watching the faces of passers by & passers home. Meet Coghill & also McColl & Coghill takes us to an to meet some friends of his. These huge shops pour out a stream of happy & tired, serious & gay humanity. 

Finally we find our friends & go to their home hoping to take them out to dinner but other arrangements with dressmakers forbid it & we wonder forth alone & tour the Boulevards till 11 pm. These are a mass of seething humanity & in it we lose Coghill.

Doc finds some friends & after leaving them Doc goes to his hotel & I sail home for mine tired after a very long day in which I have covered an enormous amount of grounds
Entry.105:
Being so tired I have difficulty in rising even by 10 am. However I just manage to get down by breakfast which finishes at 10 am & after which no one is served. 

This day I devote to south side of the river & start off by looking round the Palais du Trocadero a huge Byzantine Moorish looking building with two wings each 220 yds long in form of a crescent – enfolding a garden, aquarium etc & also a terrace with a cascade descending into a huge basin with large statues of horse, bull, elepant & rhino. 

The river is then crossed by Pont d’Iena to Eiffel Tower up which I could now ascend though the war restrictions are off & ascents will be made as soon as the café is ready. This is the loftiest monument in the world (984 ft) & indeed it looks it. 

Passing then onwards I entered the Champ de Mars supposed to be 550 yds wide but now filled up with buildings devoted to military purposes & machinery necessary to drive the wireless. Thence I visited the Hotel des Invalides this esplanade in front of which is 270 yds wide & embellished with elm trees. It was intended for an aged soldiers home & can accommodate 7000 inmates.

At the other side of building uses a Dome beneath which repose the remains of Nap 1 “on the banks of the Seine in the midst of the people I love" as was his oft expressed

104

wish. The gilding of the Dome has entirely disappeared. The Tomb of Nap 1 was not open to inspection this day In fact I am making a flying visit only in order to place everything in a proper perspective & not to minutely examine the treasures that await me & many of which are not yet restored from the secure depths where they have rested during the war. 

From Place Vauban I pass into the Boul des Invalides by Av de Villars along to Rue de Sevres where I double back to Av de Breuteuil which offer an imposing of the Hotel des Invalides – a rising dome dominating a broad strip covered with lines of trees 

Then I pass by Rue Vaugirard to the Jardin du Luxembourg reaching it by Rue de Gunemeyer Rue de Luxemburg. Here I repose in these gardens which are much the same as our gardens with quiet recesses & deeper thickets. A multitude of chairs lie around not yet in use as Spring is not properly here yet & many a private cosy corner where lovers may whisper confidential trifles. 

There a few lawns & less flowers. The trees in the avenue sprouting out of bare soil unrelieved by any green but there are plenty of spaces where children can play & so the whole family comes here & enjoys itself. Madame knitting & Pere reading his paper. In centre is a large basin surrounded with balustrades &

fountain of the Marie Medici who built the palais rises with imitations of stallactites 

I leave gardens & cross Boul St Michel into Rue Soufflot or rather I intended to but got into Rue des Ecoles whence I retraced my tracks passed the enormous Sorbonne which unlike our universities does not stand in grounds of its own but is like any other public building & loses it majesty by association & contact with its adjoining structures. The same applies to Ecole de Droit in whose rooms I hope soon to be installed. 

There better situated by itself stands the Pantheon on the highest ground on this side of river. This place was the tomb of St Genevieve the patron saint of Paris. The entrance consists of 22 fluted columns 81 ft in height similar to Pantheon at Rome. The building is empty & seems a vast waste of space, & money. There are painting around the walls in delicate tints a description of which will be found in Badeker. 

From the Pantheon I went on to find Mde Brisson in Rue Cardinal Lemoine. I located the house easily enough but the concierge was out & asked nearly every individual in place. There is a young book binder here named something like Brisson but no one is sure. Finally she arrives & instead of being the mother of Capt Brisson it is

106

his sister. I introduce myself & we yarn for a long time. Mde comes in but seems to doubt if I am not a friend of her daughter’s. Brisson is due in Paris in a month or so which will be bon for me 

I pass along Rue des Ecole past the College de France into Boul St Michel & passing downwards to the city pass the Thermal baths once belonging to the ancient palaces of the Roman Emperor Constantius Chlorus who resided in Gaul from 292 – 306. The size of these bath gives us an idea of the great size of the palace but even the Baths are now in ruins. The musée de Cluny occupies the exact site of the Palace but I did not have time to enter it 

Further down the street I met the Fontaine St Michel 84 ft high but being placed against a house it loses much of its grandeur. Near by is Rue de la Huchette & Zacharie “penetrating one of the dirtiest & most intricate & yet at the same time the most interesting & best preserved quarters of old Paris."

Passing now to the de la Cite one encounters another mass of monumental grandeur. Facing is Hotel the oldest hospital in Europe on 
left
 right is Notre Dame & on left the Prefecture of Police. All facing on to Parvis of Notre Dame Center the Cathedral whose external air is squat solid & dominating so unlike other Cathedrals

but yet the mother of many as its façade the oldest of its kind is the model for many in NE of France. Once converted to a Temple of Reason it is still a Christian Church. The interior gives one the impression of great roominess while a pale greenish light pervades the whole. On each side is a double aisles with chapels between its buttresses. It is not the lofty roominess of Amiens but a style all its own.

From the church I visited Palais de Justice occupying the site of the old Conciergerie This site is that of the old king & the Roman Governors for this was originally Paris & the rest of city is but the branches. The building is plain but indicative of great strength. 

Crossing the river I then take the 
tram
 metro for Porte Maillot & entered the Bois de Boulogne once the resort of brigand & outlaws now the rendezvous of the elect.

I pass the Café d’Armenonville et de Madna but funds will not permit a visit. I then turned to Carrefour au bout des lacs & look up along the lake crowded with boats manned by all countries none of whom have the faintest idea of rowing like our own picnic parties

I do not visit as time is short & I intend to return to Paris if the Gods permit for same reason I do not visit Jardin d’Acclimatation. 

I cross between the two Lacs near cascade but do not

108

visit the Grand Cascades which are some distance away & catch the tram at La for Hotel where I wash my feet & off again to meet my orderly 

This continual meeting of the orderly worries me more than anything else I know. It is not the money required to keep him but the subordination of unformed plans to meeting him at a definite rendezvous. 

I go to Astra for Doc but he has not returned & I desire an address from him so return till I find him. He has not been able to find the address but invites me to his room, which even in this moderate hotel costs 20 fr per day without meals. He invites me to dine with him which after a few Oporto flips I do. Dinner is with music & the head waiter chooses our dishes. Meal is very good & costs with a brule of wine (7 fr) 12 for each. 

After dinner Doc has a rendezvous with Miss Johnson & her home lies in the direction of the Casino de Paris – go there & make an arrangement to meet Doc outside at 11 am. Show is of no interest to anyone apparently for no one pays any attention to it – In the promenoir which is promenade in rear of the dress circle there beauty parades & importunes every lonely man. 

I stand by myself a little in rear by

myself & in succession I am besieged by about 30 young girls at least some are young, Their size habits, beauty & application of paint & powder all vary & their requests are never the same Sometimes it is a cigarettes that is needed & sometimes a flower or a drink & then the inevitable question. But there is no annoyance in a refusal & no complaint for wasting time.

There is nothing repellant like the same class of English girl. It is their business & while one pities their choice one does not feel disgusted with these votaries of Love or Lust.

While waiting for Doc I met Jessie Alosi an acquaintance of my friend & she took me in behind the now closing scenes of the Casino, & a rare sight it was to see these girl – women in age & intellect but romping & skylarking like a lot of schoolgirl. Truly the temperament of the French is hard to grasp. 

I wait until midnight for the Doc & many a endeavours to entice me from my tryst. However as Doc does not come I go home to the hotel where I am staying tonight Hotel Mondain 44 Rue Pigalle & am so tired that I do not get up till 11 am though I have to meet Dr at 11 am
Entry.106:
However I get to Astra later & find

110

Dr was detained & had a fine night with many whiskies & sodas & has only just got up. I slip down to nearest coiffeur & have a share & then go off to dinner with McColl & another friend we pick up en route 

We dine at the Café aux Pyramides a restaurant largely frequented by the Yanks. These obnoxious intrusions on the human race are much in evidence here. In fact they are everywhere except in the fighting line but their boasting is beyond all endurance & as they have won the war & saved civilisation & Europe (in their opinion) they consider they are entitled to boss everyone. At least that is what they act up to. 

After dinner I propose to visit Ciro & Maxims but we meet Isaackson & the three of us promenade to a where McColl wishes to buy some presents for the people with whom he has been staying. We try to seat ourselves in the open air café de la Paix but here one does not sell alcoholic drinks so we must move along to Bar

After some more Oporto flips (a drink consisting of nutmeg, whole egg, brandy & some other mixtures) Isaackson clears off & McColl & I set off for Ciro in Rue Daunou off av – de l’Opera. 

Here McColl meets an old friend with whom

he used to ride in the Bois de Boulogne & after presenting me we have a drink though more than one the girls will not take. One is as lively as a cricket & much attracts me. We afterwards make a party of 4 & decide to dine at Maxim much against the girls wishes who declare that it is too dear & not nice. However being men we are obstinate & enter the door & red vestibule of this place so famous Merry Widow 

The walls contain painting for most part of nude women & mirror & glass are everywhere, seats along the side are cushioned & the remainder is chair. If you wish to sit near the wall a table is pulled out for you. Your hats & sticks are pounced upon & everywhere flunkies surround you in the hope of a tip. The girls choose a meal that is not too expensive & dispute one of the items yet cost is 144 fr. & we have had scarcely any wine (2 carafes). 

From here we wander off without any definite plans. One girl wants to go dancing at Montmartre & this appeals to me but McColl cannot dance so we go in Folies Bergeres, & if a bergere entered into this spacious building she would be overwhelmed. The place is divided into 2 parts the first with innumerable chairs & tables & a band stand in centre on 

112

which a band plays during the intervals Inside is an enormous carpeted promenoir which is similar in its crowd to Casino the girls are more numerous. 

We go to the upper promenoir which is not frequented by the demo monde & around the exterior edge of this runs a glass promenade scintillating with light on which tight clad girls (50) gambol & on which a danseuse gives a magnificent exhibition. The costumes & staging are far more magnificent than Australia has ever 
scene
 seen 

I miss nearly an hour of the performance by going to Gare du Nord (3 frs) auto) to change my instructions to my orderly whom I do not see. Finally I return to theatre & find the cricket or rather she finds me & at end of performance we see girls to their home 134 Rue d’Henri Monnier & slip off to our hotel
Entry.107:
McColl does not rise till nearly noon & as my cash has long ago vanished With difficulty we dressed & without any coffee or midday meal unshaven just catch 1.15 train for Abbeville hoping for the best. 

The train passes out from Nous (du Nord) through pleasant villages amongst forest & undulating hills covered with verdant green, Surrey beautiful as it was on my first

impressions is lost amidst such beauty its picturesqueness is enthralling & whilst I cannot put it into words as it seemed on this first bright day of Spring still it will remain a memory of beauty 

During journey I shave & then train passes through the old battlefield area & even now the shell holes close & black serve as a reminder of the storm that has passed over but 
whose
 the memory of which will remain for many a day. 

Near Boves we passed the ruined chateau (now more ruined by Germans) where Henri IV so oft resided with the beautiful Gabrielle d’Estrees & thence into Amien where we obtained a small loaf of bread with a slice of ham (1 fr) in fact several with some substitute for chocolate & some orangers It speaks well for Maxims that we could go till 6 pm the next day without meals doesn’t it & so if meals be divided over the period Maxims was not dear eh!

Darkness has now begun to set in & the way was known to me & is described elsewhere. We reached Abbeville about 7 pm & train leave for Feuquieres I rang Division & they were unaware that battalion had shifted to Gamaches though Coghill had told me that they were there since 10th. 

I should report to Div. Wing for instruction & so rang them up. They told me

114

that battalion was to move though they had no notice of its change & so I must go to Feuquieres though I must not be surprised if battalion is not there Such is our organisation & the wonder is that we have managed to successfully blunder through the war.

However Feuquieres means a good bed & meals at Mde Boulingers so I go without wasting time & arrive to find that battalion has gone. Doc goes to his billet & I to mine. I am welcomed in like the prodigal calf & two eggs & coffee & confiture served up for me. After supper (meals this day have only cost 5 fr) I roll into bed & remain there till 11 am the following day.
Entry.108:
I have to meet Dr at 11 but remain to breakfast & then say good bye. Dr is not ready but has met the QM Prentice & a waggon will be sent to bring us over in the afternoon. 

As I do not wish to intrude on Dr billet I remain in his room till ready to start & at 2-30 pm we find our conveyance – a Maltese cart ie a cart without springs. There was a lamp in can & during the first minute this was jerked into pieces 

We put up with jolting till we

arrived at Chepy Valines & there we found a seat which was jolted to pieces in first few minutes. Thereafter I decided to walk & the private on front gave me his seat & we sat straddled across seat & in this way reached Gamaches having travelled about 7 KM to much in a 9 KM journey because driver was 34th & only knew the way via Chepy. 

On arrival I found the finest state of disorganisation that it was possible to conceive & I have been in the military some years now. No one was in charge. No one knew anything. There was not even a billet & no one seemed to care. The RC padre Major the last of the family of that name in Brittany escorted me round many places but all in vain & in despair I put up at the Hotel St Pierre (4 fr) for the night Little did I think when I dined here last that I should ever see it again much less dine in it
Entry.109:
I rose 8.30 pm & proceeded to mess. All that now remain is McKenzie De Vere Sheehan, Padree Major Wheeler & Prentice & subsequently Collier. These will probably all be on the last 
draw
 draft for home & will probably leave here about 5th May. 

I am rather anxious over my Paris course & have written 2 letters to London

116

today one to Holmes & the other to Bowden

I strike duty to night in charge of a picket which after searching for town major find that the duties are nil. My orderly has not yet succeeded in finding me though he is here somewhere. The billet is apparently the relic of a rather fine household with garage. The rooms all run one into the other & are not too springy beds. .
Entry.110:
This morning we had a route march The company (150) is also a battalion MacKenzie & myself are all the officers We go to top of hill in a biting cold wind but rain comes on & we return Rain continues all day. 

Doc returns & I arrange his transport. His leave has come through & he is bound for a job in blighty.

Afternoon is rainy but this suits me as my diary is away in arrears.
Entry.111: Rain – no parade – wet night at camp on hill to night as draft leaves to morrow –
Entry.112:
Route march this morning on Beauchamps road. Brissenden passes on motor bike. 

We spend a halt of half an hour gazing across the alluvial flats of a winding river which separates this Picardy from Normandy. The Normans who do not pray “Give us this day our daily bread" but merely “Show us this day etc" A flat topped hill rises across the flats with a ravine on either side & behind the forest of Eu full of deer & boar. Even up on the hill sides the soil is cultivated & no single foot of arable soil is lost 

We return to see draft off at 11.56 am Molesworth leaves with it. Yesterday was pay-day & the drunken songs of over indulged members of battalion comes up from courtyard but my diary is up to date so I can retire to my bed & read.
Entry.113:
To day Capt. Prentice becomes Town Major & I enter upon duties as Asst Town Major & official interpreter. 

My work consists in wandering round all the billets inquiring of all ladies in house – inspecting – & generally amusing myself & making acquaintances with all that is lovely in the town. In this way I make

118

many acquaintances & receive many invitation some of which I avail myself. 

It is surprising how many nooks & corners this little village possesses. All mills here are run by water wheels & every mill is lighted by electricity but the town & private houses are on a contract with gas Co & there is no gas since 1914 on account of shortage of coal & so if you are out late at night you are not troubled with the glare of street lights but you way is lighted by the dim religious light of the stars.
Entry.114:
This is Good Friday but here it is the same as any other day. There is a voluntary church parade & for the remainder there is a voluntary church

parade so for those who would have clean souls their bodies must remain unclean. 

For myself I set off on my billeting & inspecting job. This morning while I was away there has been a big rumpus. Some days ago I opened the door leading out of my room & finding no one there appropriated a carpet, a chair & a rug. 

This

morning a search was made for articles & although both McKenzie & Sheehan knew they were in my room yet ignorance of French prevented their saying so. So they were found in my room & as several things have been stolen they imagine they have discovered means of ingress & egress of theif.

About 2.30 pm Town Major receives a note from Maire & of course as interpreter I accompany him but no one knows what it is about. On entering the Tannerie which is where Maire spends all his time 2 women, the Maire & a surly looking man all commence speaking at the same time & had my interpreting powers to the utmost

Soon I gave up interpreting & listened & find that I am the subject of all this disturbance. I am now an excellent judge of French temperant & never make a mistake. In the end I am invited to take wine with the ladies & am shown all their treasure trove & post cards. Their front room is chaos. Birds of paradise & foxes and several good specimens are on floor & in all sorts of corners. 

However I spend a pleasant afternoon & leave the best of friends with an invitation to see them again
Entry.115:
120

Still on the stunt of billeting & this morning have to revisit a Dr Courmontagne re soldiers billets Madame implores me to leave her home alone if I can & she is ably supported by her father a Maire of a neighbouring municipality I promise to do my best & on learning that I am an avoca invites me to her home any time I am free to make the acquaintance of her husband. 

This afternoon I am deputed to take a statement from a French girl Germaine Bandelin who witnessed the death of one of our men who fell from a horse & a pleasant interview it was & laughable when a baby on the floor gave a representation of the Mannicken Pis.

This afternoon I am on a Court Martial a pleasant way of spending Saturday afternoon so we sentenced him to 12 mos hard labour which is subsequently commuted to 90 day F.P. Then I review the French girl & obtain her signature to the typewritten copy.
Entry.116:
This being Easter Sunday we decide to dine in style & really do ourselves well. Dinner consists of Soup Devil kidney & Macaroon, Roast Duck, Roast Pork Roast Beef Potatoes Green Peas

Plum Pudding & Brandy Sauce or Wine Trifle or Baked Custard or Compote Apricots & Cream Macaroons & & Coffee. Whisky Wine & cognac included. We lingered over dinner till about 3 pm. Present were Major Wheeler, Mackenzie, De Vere, Simpson, Sheehan, self, Boyes & Colyer.

After dinner I strolled up to visit Dr Courmontagne I was received most hospitably & after drinking several benedictines he suggested that as I had been discussing music with him we might adjourn with him & visit some friends M. a timber merchant from Brittany who possesses a charming wife & two lovely daughters. 

We sit down to a very pleasant afternoon tea & of the nicest cakes I have tasted here. Conversation is very interesting & enlightening one topic being should a man leave his fatherland which the two girl rigorously argued in the negative. They were curious to know all I could tell them of Australia & even if the meal had not been so excellent I should have enjoyed myself 

We lingered on till about 8 pm & as it was too late to retire to mess I thought I should miss my dinner but my hosts decided that I should stay for supper & thereafter we smoke & I finally leave their house about 11.30 pm after one of the

122

pleasantest day I have spent here 

The enlightened tone of the conversation was in itself fascinating while the eager & active part taken by the quick witted women was a revalation. 

As I said before one cannot appreciate the race which is greater than even the English race, unless one can fluently speak the language.
Entry.117:
Again I find myself on the billeting stunt & in afternoon receive a letter from Capt E R Holme & immediately forward another S40 form as all previous ones seem to have gone astray. 

I then visit my friends & find several ladies present & a barrister brother in law from Abbeville who gives me some good information re law. The conversation between the ladies of whom there are about 7 is quite different from our talk being of a breadth & depth not usually associated with women while the male element is as mercurial as a schoolboy & as light.

We see the avocat off & then I return to mess at 6.30 as I do not wish to burden them with my presence for dinner
Entry.118:
This morning all officers assembled at HQ & Colonel Farrell outlined a scheme for celebrating Anzac Day. There was to be a dance for Officers with Australian sisters from Abbeville a dance for the men & sports all the afternoon. 

After leaving here I have to turn out the Sgt mess in compliance with the Maires request as the old couple 73 & 80 years of age are too old to be put out of the even tenour of their way. 

Then Col Heron appears on scene & is taking over on Thursday. 

All the afternoon I spend looking for the dentiste but am unsuccessful.
Entry.119:
All this morning when I should be interviewing the dentist I am engaged in putting up a big tent on the hill to be used as a dancing place though how successfully I dont know as the floor is very rough & the girls are hard to find so many troops of different units have been merely passing through the village that the inhabitants are beginning to think that it is hardly worth while to fraternise & so the men are not as happy here

124

as at Fenquieres though as for myself I am more at home here than there for I have condescended to speak French. 

To night I borrow a horse & ride over to the Chinese Camp near Fenquieres to say good bye to friends but find most of them gone Little & are the only ones left. They invite me on to dinner & after dinner I return to say good bye to Mde. Boulinger & then return to join Prentice at old Battalion HQ.

Then we commence our ride home through the inky blackness lighted only by glow worms when road cuts deep into the earth. The sky is clouded & a thick driving mist damps us through & through. You cannot see 3 ft away except when the horses hoofs on the flinty stones strikes fire. 

The road between the trees beautiful by day is as mysterious in its silence by night. Not a sound even of a cricket & the tramp of the horses which seemed alien to the surroundings. Peace Perfect peace indeed it seemed but who knows what awful carnage & tragedy was being carried on in natures realm. 

Arrived back in camp about 11 pm & put the horses up & retired wet but pensive
Entry.120:
Still engaged on the tent on the hill & have not finished putting the floor down by midday. By which time I have handed over the job to the Engineers. 

I am on the draught which goes into Camp this afternoon at 3 pm. On reporting I find Capt Seaton (43) is my new OC & Tierney our adjutant. Col Farrell is in command. The draught comprises all states & will most assuredly be split up on arrival in England. 

On returning to the mess for dinner I find the place flooded with a party of French ladies from Fenquieres to whom I am presented but whose acquaintance I could have made in Fenquieres had I desired but it is too late now to do it
Entry.121:
Anzac Day – a commemoration service is held in hollow near the draught orderly room & after that we have the sports. I call upon Commandant Courmontagne to see if he wishes to go but as he is too busy with his practice I go alone & met there the Sauret family Marie & Genevieve with whom & the padre I pass the rest of the

126

afternoon & then return to billet to shift my quarters 
& when
 to 72 Grande Rue & when this is completed I speed off to the Dr for I have promised to dine with him. 

After dinner which as usual is light – soup – eggs – ham – cheese – coffee & liqueurs he receives a call from a patient near the big mill & we all adjourn for a walk where the chestnut trees now bare arch overhead & beside runs the eddying stream which serves the mill for power & the fishermen for trout.

When visit is finished we return to house & take our delayed coffee & yarn over French system of Judicature of the Justices Tribunal & Cour d’Appel. 

I return to my new lodgings on explaining my lateness to the lady of the house she takes me into kitchen to her sister & we yarn & drink real good French brewed coffee till after midnight
Entry.122:
This morning I wake later & decide that men can feed without my assistance. Before I can get out of bed the lady sends her little boy up with a cup of coffee for myself

& another for my orderly. 

On arriving in camp I find that I am in time to see mens breakfast & then have my own. After breakfast there is a medical inspection & then as day is wet parade dismisses.

In the afternoon I write up diary & letters. Went to Courmontagne & talked with a Peronne girl & then coffee
Entry.123:
Seeing the slackness that is prevailing at the camp I have decided to take advantage of it & stay in my new quarter all day. 

Last night after my yarn with the girl who was compelled to work at the point of the bayonet by the Germans during 2 years I yarned with the ladies who keep this house They are 3 sisters 46 42 & 41 but carry their age well 

We chat on & I tell them I intend to sleep in on the morrow. Consequently they send coffee up to me at 7.30 pm & then ask if I should like breakfast in bed which they send up to me. So in spite of the fact that I laid in provisions last night at the cost of 5 fr it was quite needless. 

After enormous trouble I manage to get up at midday & then having received a delayed Australian mail

128

& letter from Brisson I promptly answer them while I am in the humour. Having finished all correspondence & having written this up to date I decide to make some friendly calls & will probably be invited out to dinner

In the afternoon I visited Dr Courmontagne & find that his wife has returned & he is waiting for his little boy who is going to the picture show to come in prior to going to a musical afternoon at Saucet. Mde comes down dressed & we adjourn to the bureau of M. Benard who is the possessor of a cello & or rather viola without the E string. 

We then adjourn to Saucet & enter the room which has one side panelled to cover a series of shelves & cupboards within – a handy way of disposing of necessary but encumbering furniture. .

Afternoon tea consists of cake – followed by pastry & then light round biscuits. This is usual afternoon tea. Often a liqueur is added. 

The playing was rather good Benard made horrible face & seemed to get some notes out with his tongue judging from the way he used to roll it it. At 8 pm we adjourned Courmontaigne et supped soup – eggs – chops – cheese – pastry – (chocolate in fingers with cream interior) coffee & liqueurs Red wine through the meals.

As the family are very sleepy I retire to bed early & on arrival at my billet

find the lady of the house waiting for me with coffee. We yarn till 12 midnight & then off to bed.
Entry.124:
Snow has fallen during night & is still falling – rather unusual for this month which should be springtime weather However it is like a glimpse into the past though it is accompanied by an intense cold – rather unusual when snow is falling. 

Our camp in on top of a ridge overlooking the valley in which the town old & picturesque with its water wheels & has snugly ensconced. The panorama is continued the 
square
 fields a different shape with lie in almost impossible position on the slopes of the hill while across them runs a bare strip of road.

On other side of camp stands the hunting home of a residence & on the other side is a slight ravine running into & crowned with the glorious Loret d’Eu. Truly a panorama that I wish I could always keep in my memory. .

Snow or sleet falls all the morning & there is no parade so I loaf around in discomfort till lunch & then come down to town as McKenzie wishes me to translate a French document re Silburn who 

130

has been arrested

After this I visit the dentist & with him the café & Vasseur Reclerc, & then to billet. I dine in camp & then home where I write up notes of lectures & letters.
Entry.125:
Rain & snow with cold wind seems to have set in. However the snow yesterday all faded away by 9 am & to day the fall during the night was not visible when I got up – so we are not doing too badly after all. London has had 1 ft of snow.

Visited the Saucets this afternoon 

The relation of wife & husband here different to our idea where the woman is as good as the husband. Here she acknowledges the of protection that his strong frame & character casts over her & regards her life as belonging to him. His every 
comfort
 wish is forestalled & every comfort anticipated. His paper is brought to him & his shoes are put down alongside of him. Never have I seen the many little attentions that the wife lavishes on her husband exceeded or equalled among us. 

The daughters seem content to stay at home receive visitor serve & minister to their guests & are quite happy in that duty though they are for most part very intellectual & deeply educated. This afternoon is

pay & I have drawn 150 fr & this is to last me till I reach England. How I do not know as it will cost me 100 fr before I leave Gamaches.
Entry.126:
This morning is cold & wind cuts through through while rain clouds burst about every half hour. 

This morning receive an additional 50 men (22.35 ) & in evening – skipper delivers an address on future routine in Eng & repatriation schemes 

Dr Courmontagne is away all this afternoon & has not returned by 8 pm so after 2 calls I retire to my & drink coffee with the ladies of the house.
Entry.127:
Usual routine in morning in rain mud & loafing around awaiting dinner time, so I leave camp about 10 am & come to my billet. Gamaches is out of bounds to our men as it is supposed that there is measles in town & 2 cases have been found in camp one of them of my lot. L’Cpl Cowley.

I am undecided as to whether I shall return for dinner or not but finally do so & am immediately pounced upon as a member of a Ct to inquire into the breaking

132

of a shop window & the robbery therefrom of jewellery of Mr Leveau. When court opens we find there are 13 witnesses some of them French for whom Sgt Major S. R Duckworth has been sworn in as interpreter. Court proceedings last till 6 oclock & then only postponed till 7 which is made 8 as we have a concert party up & mess so postponed 

After Court finished I make arrangements to sleep in tomorrow morning & then to bed.
Entry.128:
Arrangements for departure still hold good in spite of measles. Rain all day. Mention to household that I am not getting up & so they send breakfast up to me in bed. Finally get up at 10.30 & have several commissions to perform 

I collect 600 franc off Hutching & finally reach camp in neighbourhood of noon. 

In afternoon I say good bye or adieu to all my friends – a somewhat painful task only relieved by the excellent wine that is supplied in honour of our last meeting not as a sign of gladness at my departure. 

I visit the Saucet & am entertained by Marie till Genevieve arrives & then sail off to the Maudint. Wine follows again an invitation to dinner which I refuse as I want to dine at Courmontagnes who have proved my

staunchest friends & have always taken me into the society of their best friends. I leave them about 11 pm. & promise to write some day & adjust a claim for them. 

Arrived at billet I say farewell to my friends from Armentieres & then to bed leaving all my packing for Melhuish in the morning. I have tried to get Melhuish on this draft but unsuccessfully so he is only a late arrival
Entry.129:
This is morn of departure & the wet weather seems likely to continue so much so that I pay a special visit to town to get my overcoat. Our contingent which is No 45 Quota falls in to time save Welbarn who is in town looking after our luggage & train leaves to time at 3 minutes to 12. 

Journey is at first in centre of a wide valley of the vividest green imaginable with a river that winds & unwinds itself in an almost unbelievable manner. Up from the valley rise hills on either side – bare of timber & cultivated forming a smooth & pleasant contrast with the forest clad summits – on both sides here for many is the exterior edges of two big forests. 

Then landscape changes to purely farming areas but the speed of train increases

134

till our combination of cattle trucks moves at a rate resembling a train. Most of the country now resembles English countries in south the villages are uniformly situated in depths of valleys whether to escape winds or on account of water supply I do not know but there are few exceptions to this rule.

This route is new to me & I have not remembered the names of the stations but we have missed all hitherto well known names. The nearest station to the camp is Harfluer so we proceed about 5 miles further on as this is the usual military way of doing things. We detrain & then have to march back again to boy leading the way. 

We go first to the old Conv. Camp for purpose of being deloused. Here rain has been heavy & everywhere you flounder through mud. As night has come on & lights are scase things are not pleasant but 
like
 luckily we strike Creighton & he show us round let us wash in his room & finally gives us a supper of preserved fruit & tea in his room. 

Our quarters here are damnable after the comfort of a bed for the last 3 mos. However I have the knack of being able to sleep anyhow & anywhere so this not not inconvenience me much
Entry.130:
This camp is for purpose of delousing everyone & organisation is very thorough

Clean underclothing is issued to everyone & while they are having a warm bath their clothes are disinfected. Every man who shows signs of chat marks is kept back for special treatment. The whole 1,000 men are put through in the one morning. The details of the scheme I did not master as all arrangements are in the hands of the Base Staff & the officers themselves go in for a warm bath

At 2 pm we shift camp to AIBD I previously went over in the morning & reserved a bed. Was told none is available but there are many here who recognise me & a bed is forthcoming. Here the company is again taken over & we have nothing to do save go on leave. I & Allen (39th Bn) decide to go in but first we must listen to a lecture by adjutant re leave etc. 

There are no trams running now as there is a tram strike on. So having missed the 1.20 pm train we must walk. It is hot & sultry & we proceed very slowly but manage the trip in 65 minutes Arrived in Havre we take a cool draught of English beer in Hotel de la Gare & most refreshing I find it & now quite. Then we wander around town. 

Allan sends telegrams & I encounter old friends from Rouen & then I take Allen down to club where I met Ferguson. Together we visit a photographer & I get 6 pc. & then

136

to Tortoni where I see Egypt & thence on to Gabriels whence we go to stations & catch train home as the leave regulations seem to have put the wind up my friends
Entry.131:
I perform all my duties for to day that is I report to the Cpl in the company orderly room & am free for the day except that I must not leave camp till 2 pm which I obey by catching 1.25 train from a station nearly a mile away – Rouelles. 

I forgot to mention that yesterday we moved into a new camp & in consequence there is a lecture to day after which I walk in to Havre through the village of Rouelles I might mention here that these stations of Rouelles & Harfleur are quite a long distance from the village of that name. 

The walk is agreeable & we go down not by the steps in Rue Montmorency but through the easy descent of Graville with its old Abbey(?) & its enormous Madonna in the cemetery & then wander round town – afternoon tea at Club a one time French house with a large circular lawn – plain & unencumbered wall Lawns where marked L. a quiet & calm retreat as the street is shut off by a high wall which in France marks so

often a beauty spot even in the middle of area blocks of apparently continuous masonry. 

We visit the Hotel Rue de la Comedie & Monics next to club where there is always dancing but take no part as we have only our heavy boots but the atmosphere is pleasant & some of the dancing is excellent.
Entry.132:
Usual hard work in the morning I superintend issue of clothing & find friends which means I get a full issue of all I require for nothing. 

In afternoon visit Havre & take a walk along the sea coast past the beaches in St Andresse see pc a walk of exceptional interest. The beach is of stones as big as clenched fist & the hill is precipitous with a large notice telling people they must not walk up the though only a goat could do so & humans must keep to the paths 

One magnificent building the Regatta Club & the modern residences seems to lack spaciousness in the grounds. One magnificent structure with a glass at end of a grotto & magnificent otherwise is absolutely spoilt by the bareness of the ground.
Entry.133:
at Club (5 fr)

tonight & then take café at Des Fleurs & then walk out a good way then return to meet Wilson who is waiting for me at Tortonis but miss him. Bethinking me of an address where dancing is reserved for officers a kid of 18 11/12 yrs who had nearly caused a murder case the previous day. 

I hurry on to find Wilson. I find myself in front of a big ship on slips in course of construction & finally get to place only to find that Wilson is not there. Hurrying back to town I meet a French officer entering a theatre & enter with him & find myself behind the scenes with a party in the middle of celebrating some ones birthday. This celebration mingled with professional dancing stunts. 

After many adventures & after climbing the Montmorency steps (255) with a of Havre a blackness illuminated by myriads of lights by the glare of shunting engines & finally arrive home about 4 am Strange to say I am not to be courtmartialled & I feel justified in ignoring these petty regulations. In fact since I have been in France I have had no official French leave & all that I have seen has been

on surreptitious leave. This night I would have stayed out all night if I could have found a congenial companion

7-8-19

I decide to pay a last visit to quant little Montivilliers & visited all places shown on p.c. The Bois a thickly wooded sunken road with a sheen on their newly shed leaves which embrace all shades of green is glorious. All the way on the right land dips into a gully cultivated on both sides & cut by a railway line on which few trains ever run perhaps for fear of destroying the rustic beauty of the place.
Entry.134:
Orders for embarkation remain unchanged. Baggage is collected at 9 am. – I ask for a coat from Scanlon but he is unable to issue it though he he QM so I ask a cpl Q.M. Coy & he at once gets me one

At 3 pm we fall in & are embarked on lorries. The men

140

have lost their rifles – their equipment & now stand with new uniforms & a kit bag. All that marching is over & here are lorries which could never be found in the days of the war. 

At 4.30 we arrive at Prince George a cross channel steamer built for 25 but only capable of doing 18 & on this trip 14 knots – We pass out through breakwater & look back at Havre glorified in a fading sun which sets tonight at 8.30 pm.

I cannot feel that I am leaving France for good but that I shall see it again though perhaps not Le Havre. In this frame of mind I settle down to dinner & do not watch the shore fade away. The sea is like glass not a wave upon it only a ripple yet many continue to get sea sick I dont know how but they did. Sunset is a failure as there is too much low lying mists 

I am on duty on deck till 1 am & then when anchor is dropped turn in. We have anchored at the mouth of river having passed Isle of Wight when passing up the – Though night is clear all that one can see is a succession of lights & lighthouses. The old Boom looms up or rather the connecting Forts.
Entry.135:
At 7 am we breakfast & up anchor. On this boat we pay for meals (3 fr each). There is little interesting in the somewhat flat shores I try to ascertain the name of a point & ask one of the crew & find that still I am unable to speak English as an Englishmen speaks it for his reply was Idenasay & it was only sometime afterwards that I released that this was not the name of the point but his inability to name it. 

We berth alongside the big Olympic & are disembarked into a shed & when all assembled we marched round to another shed & are given a meal in return for a ration ticket which had been issued at gangway. After this we are reassembled & then put through a , given a train ration & entrained by embarkation staff & we are off.

We duly arrived at Codford & are shunted back to a siding but even this leaves us ½ hour march in the hot sun for weather is very sultry & our camp is No 3. which turns out to be tents only with 12 men to a bell tent. Administration here seems to be always the same high(?) order. 

Whether from the day or the night watch or the travelling I am very tired & turn in.
Entry.136:
Usual camp routine – inspection by Rosenthal which I do not attend as I 

142

am Captain of the day but try to get leave for France & at leave office find an old Cpl of the Fieldmarshall & everything is fixed up but I must call for pass to morrow.
Entry.137:
Collect pass – big robberies of officers gear discovered this morning. My hat was stolen & then replaced. Otherwise I am intact. I pick up my pass & sail off with Thompson by afternoon train arriving in London at 7.45 pm after waiting nearly 2 hours at Westbury. 

At Carlton Gardens find that leave officer has moved & we inquire at Regent Palace. These have no rooms for 3 mos but send us to a place Park House 16 & 17 Bayswater Tce, overlooking the Kensington Gardens & kept by an Austrian (once) named Hardy 

The search for this place involves some effort as houses here are divided into sections & each section is numbered on its own.
