So that numbers may be running down & suddenly you get a heavy throwback & as usual London people are too stupid to explain anything & police we could not find. People are too respectable here perhaps. We find light refreshments nearby & then to bed.
Entry.138:
As we are both going to France we set off for Horseferry road for our passports

On arrival at Horseferry I find that I can get leave for Venice Rome & Naples just as easily & do so 

At sometime I try to collect the money that was due to me in Rouen on March 13 but was not paid as value of franc had decreased but found that even now it was impossible to draw it. 

Then aimed with letter from Horseferry visited War Office. A most formidable place. You enter write yourself a pass state nature of business & Room this is initialled by by a flunkey & you are handed over to a little girl who takes pass & conducts you to your room 

Room 114 is out at 12.45 & will not resume his arduous labours till 2.30 pm so I am given my pass & walk out the way most people are going & being in uniform though wearing Australian hat am taken for staff & am allowed to leave while the all important pass rests in my pocket. 

On arrival back at 2.30 I march in & surprise the police by informing them that I still have a pass & am told where room is but go straight & do not appear lost or ask questions & I can go then without the guide. The whole place swarms with youngsters & flunkeys

At 3.30 the overworked staff adjourns for tea. During the hour I put in the only person who did any work was the typist. The wonder is how anything is ever done in this asylum for Englands incompetents. Of course

144

after this it was too late to go on with passport as all offices close at 4 

In evening we went to Chu Chin Chow now in 4th yr. & were disappointed. It contains all the of barbaric display & has natives from different parts of world.
Entry.139:
Get passport issued but not vise Thompson having wired to Codford decides it will be best & quickest to ride 300 miles in the train & bring the reply himself which turns out best as telegram does not arrive till 3 day after he has returned with the permission. 

I visit Museum, Art Gallery & generally wander over London into places that I have not seen, & dine at night at Gustaves who chat with me & drink cognac till 11.40 pm
Entry.140: Continue my wanderings of London but forget exactly where. Get passport vise for nothing this usually costs 8/- Thompson leaves for France. I dine Au Petit Riche & say farewell to Elise. Get NME approval & am told to report back
Entry.141:
Bought shirt etc at Ordinance for £1 – no uniforms Saw funeral of Cavell – Band playing Chopin – visited army & Navy stores – Alcocks Kennedy – on way home met some French ladys on way to Elysee dance near Queens Rd. 
Lond
Entry.142:
Have breakfast in bed always at this place – it is the only meal they serve & catch train back to camp. 

The countryside is a glorious patch of enclosed fields with yellow buttercup lawns & flowering white hawthorn hedges whilst everywhere trickles small rivulets. 

I arrive at camp & no one knows anything of NME & I wish I had stayed in London as this trip has cost me 16/- & a fatiguing walk of nearly 3 miles to camp. After dinner I wander up on the hill which rises steeply in rear of our quarters. 

The whole side is covered with primrose & daisy & a small blue flower a glorious 
coloured
 carpet of colour while as if this were not beautiful enough, every flower is connected with silvery threads of spiders forming a silken avenue stretching away to the setting sun. The scene below is beautiful. 

All fields now covered by the young crops are carpets of vivid green below like a snake amongst the lovely winds with many a twist a little rivulet which somewhere perhaps becomes a river. The picturesque train (now normal length 10 carriages) in the distance with typical white steam – the hedges now irregular with over hanging boughs – here & there a thicket or copse and a plantation denser by its very isolation form a picture that one only expects to see in a book. 

Although it is 8.45 the sun

146

is a long way from setting though the drowsy tinkling of the little squares of sheep suggest that is time for repose. Along the river bank flourish the populas with knobby heads picture like, while overhead the lark thrills out his song.

To the left thro dense tree top glimpses can be seen of Wylie & it square church tower & the only blot on this beauteous landscape is the silent & abandoned camp beneath. There is another aspect & that is the economic. There is much waste land here not as France is the ground used to its full advantage.

17-5-19 (Sat)

No new has so far arrived so I decide to finish my leave. Exchange a hat & start off for station – find that I have just missed the 10.36 & must wait till 1.5. Then arrive at Salisbury & porter takes charge of my gear, & I buy some pc to replace those I lost. Met a NZ & we drink several vermouths the only drinks I have on this leave, arrive in London & find my room kept.

18-5-19 (Sun)

Intended to go to Brighton but do not rise till nearly 3 pm & then not knowing where to go I ask a policeman & he puts me on to Hampton Court As this is Sunday the day

when all the old trees in the avenue that is ¾ mile long thro Busby Park are all in bloom all the world is going there & after waiting an hour for a bus with standing room on it I take Tube to Shepherds Bush where no bush exists & then tram.

I enter into the Court itself & pass through the building See guide – then go thro the room Then see the Great vine 5 ft in girth at its root & 4 ft 7 in 1 ft above ground Then the pretty Italian garden with its arches in shrub & in centre its low fountain & at far end its Venus hidden grotto. Then I go along the three grand avenues all opening from Kings window and edges with magnificent – a quicker growing tree than beech. 

Thence I pass along to Chestnut Avenue & walk along to Teddington & then retrace my steps & walk to Knightsbridge (2 Kingston) & meet a Socialists who yarns with me & tells me to call in at Socialist Club Fitzroy Square & ask for Mr Keel & say Hayes sent me. These men I found for the most part to be idealists with impracticable philosophical ideas but a few of them were bomb throwers Hegarty.

Finally reach home having had nothing to eat since breakfast & having walk about 8 miles or more

19-5-19 (Mon)

Visited Lady Harrowby & make arrangements to stay at Manor House Surrey 

Mrs Rutson

148

one of the Buxtons of South African fame & Miss Davison & Bartlett Matthews give me some addresses at Paris. Arrange that I set out to morrow. I then visit many places & people in London, the order of which I have now (28/5/19) forgotten. 

I dine tonight at Chinese café & find it very agreeable to be eating bamboo again. The meal they give is one of the biggest in London. 

The previous evenings I have dined at the Restaurant Espagnol 27 Dean St. Soho Sq.W. Bill Coverta 3 Tortilla 1/6 Staeck 1/9 Fritto 6 Compot 9 Coffee 4d = 5/1. Previous evening Coverta 3 Sopa 6 Filet Plaice 1/6 Cocido 2/6 Compot 9 Coffee 4 =
Entry.143: In evening I visit Socialist Club & am present at a big fire in Tottenham Ct Road.
Entry.144:
Visit tailors in Savile Row & find their prices for uniform is 11 to 12 gns far beyond my purse & then catch 1.15 train to Weybridge which is about 2 ½ miles from the Manor House but is nearest station I am met by a South African officer who is staying there & driven in a little cart with a small wee pony just like a big dog.

We pass Brooklands & finally reach the House an old royal hunting lodge used by Ed.II & then presented by James I to his Queen Anne of Denmark who enlarged it. Much of the original building is said to remain but I doubt it. The grounds are beautifully

laid out so enraptured am I that I have taken plans & intend to copy it if I can when I get home. 

The back with its formal garden & rectangular paths, square plots of grass & ornamental yew flanked by hedges & yew gateways is very pretty whilst in the centre a huge hornbeam gives a lovely shade where afternoon tea is enjoyable below is a terrace & then lower still the tennis court flanked by 6 scotch firs 300 yrs old & then the river or rather back water & in the distance the far stretching field though not too far for Surrey is always hedged in

On left is a wilderness full of Rhodendron & azaeleas in full bloom which has completely caught my fancy for in a small space it has very long walk & 4 rustic bridges over a lake full of water lilies. The very fact that it has gone wild adds to its beauty in my eyes. 

In the afternoon Miss Heaton Ellis & Miss come over & we start off with tennis for which I am very much handicapped having no slacks. Then follows afternoon tea in the shade of the thick hornbeam in the formal garden & the cool breeze that comes across while we recline in easy cane chairs reminds me of our cool breezes

The weather is delightful here. Bright sunshine & cool breezes, hot if you are working but pleasant if you are loafing around. 

Tonight there is a dance & although I do not intend to dance I go & meet

150

there a Miss Stoops daughter of a Judge & one of the knobs of the neighbour . She is pretty-ill-mannered & swollen with ideas of her own importance. The Pinches are girls of the Australian type while Miss Ellis is coarse physically & mentally but seems to has caught & landed a neighbour named Lt Cpl Barnes DSO at present at Foxholm

The rooms have glorious beds with sheets as soft as down. Electric legal & reading light with a little book case attached A bay window open over a clump of lilac in bloom & a small walled garden with arches in walls. Electric bell is at side of bed.
Entry.145:
Breakfast at 9 for which I am late due to the big plunge bath near my door. Style of service is help yourself though there is no fire to keep plates warm. Boiled egg, fish or fish puree, bacon form usual menu with coffee or tea & jams (often black currant). 

Mrs Rutson has gone to London to day & I loaf round & bask in the sunshine & examine the wilderness with its little lawns & flower bed & wild overgrown paths of lilac & rose. 

In afternoon we drive over to Pinches in the dog cart & after inquiring of all & sundry including tradesmen who do not know the Pinches though they have resided in the same house for 20 yrs – a usual example of English intelligence – we find Louise & play tennis in middle

of which I have to in pony & go to Byfleet to meet Mrs Rutson & finally dine at 8 pm & spend evening in the library.
Entry.146:
Mrs Rutson goes to London again but leaves Harris & myself a job of falling trees as we are going on the job we find several pieces of Italian marble evidently a pillar & groping around find all the pieces & erect the pillar

While working at trees the old housekeeper Cruickshank, a scotswoman who has already taken a fancy to me because I am so jovial & cheery & decides I must be Scotch why even my name is scotch & all my good points are Scotch. She speaks of 
our
 folks & their habits so different from the English etc. She bring lemon drink & retails all the ghosts she has seen in the house the jester (responsible for rich panelling) Henry VIII, , Queen Anne, & tells us she has actually seen the ghost of a woman in room next to mine but I do not see or hear her during my sojourn here.

In afternoon we row up the river Wey to Mrs Horthams who takes us over the gardens of the Royal Horticultural Society. These gardens present a beautiful display of every possible kind of flower the Rhodendrons & azaleas being particularly fine but taken as a whole garden is not beautiful I prefer Mrs Rutsons wilderness. The river is pretty but I prefer the wildness of the Lane Cove

152

to this insipid & regular beauty.

We return early & play tennis with the Pinches & then dine about 8 pm, egg & – liver with puree & – prunes etc – beer.
Entry.147:
Harris goes to station to meet Miss Wade a pretty doll who might have been a woman if she had lived in any other country than England & had allowed her natural temperament to develop & not be warped by the bonds of conservatives & reticence. 

I spent the morning making plans of the wilderness. In afternoon Coller, Ellis & another nurse turn up & play tennis. I take walk down the river to the mill rail but pass no place more beautiful than the Manor House. 

Night we 
play cards
 row up the river with Mrs Rutson & Miss Wade.
Entry.148:
Yarn on lawn with Miss Wade – Weather is delightful warm with a cool breeze & air languid. In the afternoon some S. African friends arrive & I row them up the river to the currents that are as swift that navigation ends especially with a girl steering. The river is pretty or rather it is only a creek with a strong current.

At night we play a game of cards called or some such name & then off to our rooms where I write till 1.2
